GUILTY . Aged 16—
Confined One Month the first and last week to be solitary.

557.
WILLIAM SIGGINS was indicted
for stealing, on the 29th of January, 1 gown, value 5s., the goods of
John Attwood.

JOHN ATTWOOD . I live near the Wellington public-house, at Highgate, and am a milkman. on the afternoon of the 29th of January I was near the Wellington, about a quarter past two o'clock, and saw the prisoner running up the hill with a bag and a gown in his possession—he went a few yards and up the gown into the bag—I went and asked my wife if she had lost any thing, and she missed a gown off the line—I ran after the prisoner, and called to a person to stop him—he turned round and saw me, and shook the gown out of the bag—I took it, up and gave him into custody.
DAVID HALEY . I live at Highgate. I saw the prisoner go into Mr. Attwood's yard and come out again, but I cannot tell what he took—he had a bag, but no basket.
MARY ATTWOOD . This is my gown—I laid it out to dry on the line in the yard—my husband came to me, and I missed it.
Prisoner's Defence I was out with crockery—a man said, would I buy a gown; I gave him a very handsome set of jugs for it—I had two or three more houses to got to, and this man came and took me.
(Mary East and Eliza Freestone gave the prisoner a good character)

GUILTY . Aged 20—
Confined One Month.

558.
WILLIAM STEWARD . was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of January, 4 shirts, value 7s.; 1 night-cap value 1s.; 2 pairs of drawers, value 2s.; 2 petticoats, 1s., 6d.; 5 handkerchief, value 14s.; 1 pair of stocking value 4s.; 1 dressing-gown, value 3s.; 5 towels value 2s.; 1 habit-shirt, value 8s.; 2 table-cloths. value 1s.; 6d.; 25 towels, value 10s.; 2 dusters, value 6d.; 2 window-blinds, value 2s.; and 7 knife cloths, value 6d.; the goods of
William Russell; 4 shifts, value 5s.; 2 caps, value 1s.; 1 petticoat, value 1s.; and 5 handkerchief, value 3s.; the goods of
Mary Ann White; and 1 basket, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
Winifred London—2nd stating them to be the goods of
Samson Tasker.

SAMSON TASKER . I am a carrier. A basket of lines was entrusted to my care on the 16th January, about six o'clock by Mrs. London, the laundress—I brought it safely to Lincoln's-inn-fields, and was going to deliver that and two other basket at Squire Russell's—I took in two; and while I did that, this third basket was gone—I ran down the square and saw it on the pavement, ten or twelve yards from the cart—I took it into Mr. Russells'

WINIFRED LONDON . I gave three baskets to the witness in the take to Mr. Russell's—he lost the largest, which contained all the articles stated in the indictment—they were Mr. William Russell's property—Mary Ann White is lady's maid there, four shifts and some other things were hers—the basket was nine.

JAMES TAYLOR . I am a private in the Grenadier Guards. I was walk
ing along the side of Lincoln's-inn-fields about a quarter before seven o'clock, and saw the prisoner take the basket from the tail of the cart—he took it on his left shoulder—a man behind me said, "What do you do with this? it does not belong to you"—he threw it down on the pavement and ran off—I ran after him and seized him—he asked to let him go—I said I could not—I brought him back to Mr. Russell's

GUILTY . Aged 30.
Transported Seven Years.

559.
JOHN TOWERS was indicted
for stealing on the 21st January, 4 brushes, value 4s. 6d., the goods of
Charles Foulger.

ELIZA STEWART FOULGER . I am the wife of Charles Foulger, who lives in Paradise-row, Islington, and is an oilman—on the 21st of January these four brushes were brought me, and I then missed them from where I had placed them.
Prisoner I had them given to me by a man in the Hackney-road to take to Islington—he gave me a shillings, and I spend four-pence of it.

THOMAS GABITASS . I was in the police at the time. I was on duty about six o'clock in the evening of the 20th of January, at Smith's-build
ings, and saw the prisoner under a gateway—I asked what he was doing—he said he wished to see a person named Kemp—I said that side-door was never opened—I brought him with me round to the front door—the people said no person named Kemp lived there—I took him to the station, and found these brushes on him—I enquired for Mr. Kemp, but could not find him.
(Robert Burdett, a silk-weaver, Cheshire-street, Bethnal-green, gave the prisoner a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 15—
Confined Two Months.

560.
GEORGE BARRON was indicted
for stealing on the 30th of January, 1 handkerchief value 4s., the goods of
John Marshall, from his, person.

JOHN MARSHALL . I live in George-street, Adelphi, and am a corn
merchant.

About half-past four o'clock in the afternoon, on the 30th of January, I was going down Coventry-street—I felt a tug at my pocket—I turned and seized the prisoner with my left, hand, with my other hand I took this handkerchief, which he was concealing in his bosom—it is mine—he was very peaceable, and burst out crying—he did not deny the charge.
RICHARD DUDLEY (police-constable C 56) I was called, and took the prisoner and this handkerchief.
Prisoner's Defence I had been out of work six weeks—I saw the handkerchief hanging out of the gentlemen's pocket—hunger tempted me to take it.

GUILTY . Aged 18—
Confined One Month.

561.
MARY MILTON was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of De
cember, 3 sheets, value 6s.; 1 table-cloth, value 3s.; 1 handkerchief, value 1s. 6d.; 7 gowns, value 4s.; 2 petticoats, value 2s.; 2 pillow-cases, value 2s.; 1 clock, value 2s.; 1 shawl 2s.; 1 pair of trowsers, value 4s.; and 1 waistcoat value 2s.; the goods of
Joel Wright, her master.

JOEL WRIGHT . I live in Clerkenwell, and am a bricklayer. The pri
soner was in my service—it was her business to look after my children, my wife having died on the 23rd of November—she absconded on the 20th of December, while I was gone out to work, leaving my child my child who was lying bad with the small-pox—I gave the prisoner 5s. a week, and her victuals—I left her 1s. a day to get what she wanted, and she had the book to get shop things—when she was I missed three sheets, and all the things stated—these are them.
JOHN MOSS . I am a pawnbroker, and live in Goswell-road. I have as shawl, and a waistcoat which was pawned by the prisoner.
WILLIAM BRITTAIN . I produce a pair of trowsers a waistcoat, and a number of other articles pawned by the prisoner.

WILLIAM ALLEN (police-constable G 38) I went to King's Head-court Westminster, and took the prisoner—I said I must search the room for the duplicates—she there was no occasion for that, she would give them to me, which she did—she said, did Mr. Wright want to prosecute her, if he got his things again—I said that I could say nothing about—her hus
band went with me to take her—he was taken first, and said if he was liberated she would give information where the things were.

GUILTY . Aged 35—
Confined Six Months.

562.
HARRIET PAVITT was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of January, 1 gown, value 2s.; 1 shirt, value 2s.; 1 apron, value 6d.; and 1 pair of half-boots, value 2s.; the goods of
George Perryment.

SARAH PERRYMENT . I am the wife of George Perryment, who lives in Old Montague-street, Whitechapel, and is a looking-glass maker. On the 20th of January. I went out for about half an hour and when I re
turned, I met the prisoner in my passage—in about a quarter of an hour I missed this apron and other things—I knew her by sight.
Prisoner You not see me for eight or mine months before, since I left my situation—you never met me in the passage. Witness Yes I did.
MARY COX , I am the with of Richard Cox, of Alaric-street, St. George's The prisoner brought this shirt to my house that evening.

JOHN FORWARD (police-constable K 181) I went and found the pri
soner wearing this gown.

GUILTY . Aged 20—
Confined One Month.

p.hi: Second Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

div1.p:
563.
THOMAS CASEY was indicted
for a misdemeanor.
MESSRS. BULLOCK and GURNEY conducted the Prosecution

WALLER WITNERS . I shall be twelve years old next birth-day, and live with my father, in Noble-street, City. The defendant keeps a cool
shed in Monkwell-street—I have been in the habit of buying coals there—on the last Friday in January, I went there to buy some coals—I found Mr. Casey and a boy there—I told him my father wanted half a hundred weight of coals—I saw him put them into the scales—before he did that he put a 7lb. weight on the other side against the wall—I them went home, and told my father—I went back again, and told Mr. Casey to send the coals home with me, and they were sent directly—I went with them to my father's.
COURT. Q. Did you go with the coals all the coals way from Casey's house, to your father's? A. Yes—nobody interfered or took any out—that I swear.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. This was in the evening, was it not? A. Yes—I am quite sure that this was in the shop all the time—I hesitated because I had some doubts—I am quite sure he is the man—I am not sure that he is the man that was there.
MR. GURNEY. Q. Was the person that was there dressed differently to this man? A. Yes; he is cleaner. I never saw the gentleman in such clothes before.
COURT. Q. Had your father dealt there long for colas? A. Yes—the man did not always serve me—the boy did sometimes—I do not know him in those clothes.

MR. DOANE. Q. You saw the person who served you put a weight into the scale? A. Yes; he deliberately took in off he floor, so that I could see very plainly—I did not say thing to him, or cry out—I did not like—the weight was there when I went back—when the coals were taken, a person named Sharp was there—he took he weight off—he was not there when I first went in—he came in afterwards.

THOMAS WITHERS . I am the witness's father, and have been in the habit of having coals of the prisoner. On the 29th of January, my son came back about the coals he afterwards went back to Casey—the prisoner is the person who keeps the coal-shed—I saw the coals with when my son came with them—I asked the boy whether he and brought me good weight, and told him to put them on the floor in the bag—I then took hold of the bag. I took them to Mr. Haine's, in Noble-Steet, and saw them weighed—there they were 5lbs. short of weight, besides the bag—I went directly to Casey's shop—I saw him, and said, "Halloo, Governor, I am doubtful whether you sent my right weight of coals"—his boy had brought the coals back with me—the prisoner made an answer to that—a person named

Sharp, asked for a light to look at the Scales—I examined the scales, and found behind the scale in which the coals were put, next to the wall, on the swivel, 1 7lb. weight behind the scoop—I pointed that out to Casey, and asked him what that did here—He said he not know, he knew nothing about it, he had not put it there—I told him I thought it was a great imposition, I though he had been robbing me nicely.

Cross-examined. Q. He said he he knew nothing about it? A. Yes—the weight was not fixed, it was temporarily hooked on, hanging outside the scoop next the wall—Sharp was hear me before I saw it—he took a candle and looked behind, or he could not have seen the weight—I can swear Sharp did not put the weight there.

THOMAS HENRY HAINES . I am a cheesemonger, and live at No. 19, Noble-street. Mr. Withers came to me, a man and a boy accompanied him with a bag of coals—they weighed, to the best of my recollection, 49lbs. which is 7lbs. short of the half cwt., allowing for the sack.
MR. DOANE addressed the Jury on behalf of the defendant.

GUILTY . Aged 31—
Fined £10, and
Confined Six Weeds.

564.
WILLIAM ROTHERHAM was indicted
for that he, having been declared a bankrupt, feloniously did conceal part of his personal estate, to the value of 10l., and upwards.
MESSRS. WIGHTMAN, CLARKSON, GURNEY, and BAILEY, conducted the Prosecution
WILLIAM FOR . I am a warehouseman. I have known the prisoner from seven to nine years—he has carried on the business of a linen-draper, in Shoreditch.
Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. Did you know him intimately? A. Nothing his transactions in business—he kept, I believe as many as thirty of forty persons in his establishment.

GEORGE WARD . I am clerk to Ellis and Everington, and have been se about nine years. Mr. Everinton jointed the firm in August, 1834—I have known the prisoner four or five years—he was in the habit of dealing with out firm—some of these bills (produced) are drawn by Wynne Ellis alone, and the others by Ellis and Everington—they are accepted by Wil
liam, Rotherham, the prisoner—I think I can speak to his hand-writing—I believe these to be is hand-writing—I have seen him accept bills.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. Do you mean you saw him ac
accept some of these bills? A. I cannot say positively that the accepted all these, but some of these are my writing—it has been usual for me to draw them, at his house, and he has accepted them—I have often seen write—I believe they are his hand-writing.

(The bills produce by the witness were as follows:—one for 68l. 15s., one for 203l. 19s., one for 247l. 18s., and one 50l. 9s. 6d.) MR. BODKIN. Q. To what extent has the prisoner dealt at your house in the last few years? A. I do not know—I cannot swear that it has not been to the amount of 4, 000l

WM. GLAZEBROOK DRESSER . I am collecting-clerk to Messrs. Leaf. Cole Son, and Co. warehouseman, in Old Change. The prisoner was indebted to them in the beginning of October last—in consequence of some instructions from my employers, I called on him in Shoreditch, on the 4th of October.

1834—I saw one of the clerks—I told him I called for our account, from Leaf and Co.—I do not think I mentioned the sum—he left the counting-house, and went out at a back, door, through a door at the end of the counting-house—I cannot say exactly what time it was—I should think about one o'clock—I do not know where that door led to—he stayed out about ten minutes—I received an answer a person—I do not recollect whether it was the same, that "Mr. Rotherham is out, but we will send a cheque on"—I went away—I went there on the day preceding for the same purpose, and applied in a similar way—I do not recollect the answer I got—I did not get the account.

Cross-examined. MR. BODKIN. Q. You delivered the message to a clerk in the counting-house, when do not know? A. Yes, and on the Tuesday after, I believe, a portion of the account I called for was paid—he paid 130l., part of that accounts, on the 9th October—within a week, or a few weeks, he paid the rest—the whole amount was 150l. 14s. 3d—I believe Leaf and Co. did not afterwards supply him with goods on credit—I cannot tell whether they supplied him on cash, because they would not then came into the ledger.

FREDERICK COLLIER . I was a clerk at the at the prisoner's and was so in the latter part of 1834. I remember Mr. Dresser calling at the bankrupt's several times, about the latter end of September, and the beginning of Oc
tober, 1834. I remember his coming on the 4th of October for a settlement of an account which I believe was then due—he told me he came for a set
tlement of the account—I said I did not think Mr. Scafe was in the way—he then asked me whether he could see Mr. Rotherham—I told him I would go and see—I went up stairs, and saw Mr. Joseph Rotherham and Mr. William Rotherham together, in the parlour—I told Mr. William Ro
therham that Mr. Dresser, the clerk from Leafs' was waiting below, and wished to see him—he told Joseph Rotherham to go down and speak to hi—I believe Joseph Rotherham left the room first—that was all William said, that I remember—Joseph Rotherham went into the counting-house, though I did not go in with him—I went into the back warehouse, and suppose Joseph Rotherham spoke to Dresser—I saw his lips moving, though I could not hear him.

JOSEPH BENFOLD . In November last. I was assistant to Mr. Willis, the officer of the Sheriff of Middlesex. I went to the prisoner's house on the 15th of November, in the afternoon—Mr. Wm, Willis, jun was with me—we went to arrest the prisoner—we went into the shop in Shoreditch, and asked for Mr. William Rotherham—Willis waited outside, till I had been in a necessary time for him to come in—I asked if Mr. William Rotherham was at home—the first person I saw was his brother—I cannot recollect his Christain name, but think I should know the person if I were to see him—there were several other in the shop—I said, "I have a letter for Mr. William Rotherham, "and asked to see him—he said he was not home—that was before I told him I had a note for him—I told him that it was of particular importance that I wanted to see him—he then said, if I would give him the letter, he would go and see—I gave him the note—he then went immediately out into a passage, and up stairs; and I followed him—he did not ask me to follow him—I saw him give the letter to his bro
ther, the prisoner, in the room up stairs—I was outside at the time, but I saw into the room—I followed into the room, and saw the prisoner break the letter and read it—there was some other person in the room, but I cannot recollect who it was—his brother went of the room, when I

went in—the wanted to know what business it was—he said he knew nothing about it—I said, "The fact is, I have called from Wynne Ellis respecting his account"—he then said it was not him, it was his bro
ther—I told him that I had a writ against him—he said it was not him, it was his brother (his brother was not there at the time)—I then said he must have great assurance to take and open his brother's letter—I can scarce recollect whether his brother came back, but I think he did—I told the prisoner he must go along with me, I should not leave him—he said, "Take me at your peril"—I told him I should do so, and he repeated the words over or three times—I died take him—he was in his shirt sleeves—he had no coat on—he called for his coat and boots—after he had been there some minutes he attempted to go out of the room—I told him be should not go, unless I went with him—he did go, and I followed him—he seemed very angry because I followed him—he put his coat and boots on—I took him into the street, and the officer was sitting in the shop—the prisoner came out at the side door into the street—I had not hold of him then—I had touched him before—Mr. Willis saw me pass the door, and he came out of the shop, and jointed me—I said to Mr. Willis, "Mr. Rotherham denies his name—he says his name is not Wil
liam, he is not the person we want"—Mr. Willis asked him what his name was—he said, "I am not the person you want—my name is not William Rotherham, and at your peril touch not—Willis said, "Tell me what your name is"—he said he would not—Willis then said to me, "Go and fetch one of the shopmen out"—I went and told one of the shopman that Mr. William Rotherham wised to speak to him immediately—the shopman came out and asked me where he was—I said, "He is close by, I believe—that is Mr. William Rotherham, is it not?—he said, "Yes"—I said, "He wishes to speak to you"—the shopman the made towards him; and when he got close to him, William Rotherham said, "That will do, I shall not want you now"—he did not make any other remark at that time—we then brought him away to the lock-up-house, in Cursitor-street, Chancery-lane.

Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. I believe the debt was paid that same night? A. I cannot tell that, he was discharged, I believe that same evening—I cannot whether he was discharged—I did not see him—I did not know it till I was told of it the next day—I was not there the next day, to my knowledge—I cannot say whether I was or not—not to my know
ledge—I heard he went of the next day—I live in St. John's-square—I have got my living for he last three years by going with the Sheriff's officers—that is the only way—I am married—my wife is alive—I have no family—I shall not answer the question whether I am living with my wife—I do not think it is a legal question—I think it is not proper to answer it, it is bringing family affairs into publicity.

Q. Have you ever been taken up, or charged with bigamy? A. No, never I have never been taken to any office, or charged with any thing—I have never been charged with bigamy—when I called, I saw the pri
soner's brother—I do not know his christian name—he told me he was his brother—Mr. Willis gave me the note—it came from our office—it was sealed—I might have written it, but I cannot tell—it was given to Joseph—it is not here, nor a copy of it—the first I saw was the prisoner's brother—after the prisoner had got it, and read it, he said he was not the person; it was directed Mr. William Rotherham—and upon the that he put on his boots and coat. and was about the room, and I said he was my prisoner,

and I should take him—those were my expression—I might have Said more, but I do not recollect that I did after he had read the note I pro
duced a writ, and gave him a copy of it—I have not got it now—we do not keep them.

MR. WIGHTMAN. Q. Was that a real letter or a sham letter? A. It was a sham letter, purposely for an introduction, to get an interview with Mr. William Rotherham, and his name was in full on the letter—he was the person we want to arrest—the prisoner is the man.

WILLIAM WILLIS, JUN . I am the officer to the sheriff of Middlesex. I went with the last witness to arrest Mr. William Rotherham, on the 15th of November—I went to the shop after Benfold had been in some time—he took a letter with him—I went into the shop and inquired if Mr. William Rotherham was at home—the young man said he did not know—while I was there I saw Mr. William Rotherham and Benfold pass the door in the street—I walked out after them, and saw them together—Benfold said, "Never mind; I am not the person you want, and at your peril take me"—he was then going to walk away—I said, "No, stop a moment; I must know who you are before I take you, if your name is not William Rotherham"—I told Benfold to go into the shop and tell one of the young men that Mr. William Rotherham wished to speak with him outside—I said that in the presence of William Rotherham—we were all three standing together—Benfold went into the shop and fetched out a young man—when he came out he came towards the prisoner, and the prisoner said, "That will do, "I think he said Edward; "I am the man you want"—he said to the young man, "You may go back;" "I am the man you want"—I then took him to the lock-up-house.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. What lock-up-house did you take him to? A. Slowman's in Cursitor-street-we generally take them there if they wish it—he wished to go there, because Mr. Slowman would give an undertaking for him—Benfold was in the habit of going there with me sometimes, and by himself sometimes—I believe he did not go with me there the next day—I did not go myself—I herd that the prisoner was discharged the next day—that was not through Benfold going to make in
quiries—I heard it from my brother—I did not write this letter—it might be Benfold or my father—I could tell if I saw it—it was sealed up in the usual way—he denied that he was the person we wanted, and said his name was not William Rotherham—I then went into the shop—not a word was said about Leaf's house in my presence—I can give you a notion of the contents of the letter.

THOMAS EDWARD STUBBS . I am a officer of the Court of Bankruptcy I produce the fiat issued against William Rotherham, and likewise the ad
judication—it appears upon the fiat that it is entered up on record, and the fiat is signed, "John Thomas Church".

(It appeared by the proceedings that several meeting had been held by adjournments, on the 9th and 23rd of January, 2th of February, 31st of March, 9th of April, 7th and 26th of May, 2nd and 19th of June, and the 2nd and 9th of July, the prisoner having made the usual oath that he had made a full disclosure of his estate and effects.)

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. Did you attend all the meetings? A. No; all but his first surrender, and the paper signed by Mr. Meredith—the prisoner all through protested against his commission, and I have heard that he took proceedings to try the validity of it—I have seen Mr.
Asharst attend with him, as his attorney—I have heard it has been tried at Westminster.
MR. WIGHTMAN. Q. What became of that action? A. I have heard the bankrupt was nonsuited.

HENDERSON SCAFE . I went into the prisoner's service as clerk on the 4th of December, before the bankruptcy—that was in December, 1834—among other employment, I was in the habits of going to the Bank of England for the purpose of taking the monies taken in the shop to be ex
changed for notes—I took monies to the bankers occasionally for him—I remember, on the Monday previous to the bankruptcy, the prisoner giving me cheques and cash to the amount of about 250l.—on the Saturday I had taken to the London and Westminster bank about 215l. in small notes and cash—my instructions were to get them exchanged for large notes.

Q. Was the transaction on the Monday at the Bank of England? A. yes; he gave me small notes and cheques to the amount of 250l—I got partly money and partly notes for the cheques—I then proceeded to the Bank of England with the whole, and got large notes—the largest note I received was a £200 note—I had not put anything on the notes I brought from the bankrupt, and from the bankers in Lombard-street, till I got to the Bank, when I wrote "William Rotherham" on the top of the notes—(looking at some notes) here is the name on every one of these—I received a £200 note, and delivered it to the bankrupt—I do not remem
ber what amount of cash I had in gold and silver, but I received a ticket like this (looking at one)for the gold—that was given under the gallery—I never received a £200 note for the bankrupt except on those occasions, on the Saturday before, when I took some money to the London and West
minster Bank, and the £200 note which I got at the Bank of England.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. I see you wrote the name on the top; was it always your customs to do that with the notes you took? A. Certainly, when I went on similar occasions, which I frequently did.

WILLIAM TAYLOR . I am one of the clerks in the Bank of England. I have the book of entries here—at the date of 5th of January, last year, I find an entry of the payment of a £200 note, No, 1562, dated 18th December, 1834, paid to the name of Rotherham—I received twelve notes, amounting to 115l. and a ticket from the tellers of 85l. paid in cash—this is the cash ticket, and twelve notes which amount to 115l.—these I delivered a £200 note of the number and date I mentioned—I posted the note, and William Higham paid out the note—the pay-clerk calls the number and date of the note.

Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. You do not speak as to the number and date of the notes you have before you? A. No; the pay-clerk is liable to make a mistake certainly, I depend upon the sound I hear—Mr. Higham is the person who would pass the note from the box to the party applying—I call the number to him, I had the twelve notes and the teller's ticket—I enter them, asking the individual what we wishes—he replies a £200 note—I turn to my two hundreds, and say, "One 200—62, "which is chequed by my partner, and he gives it from my direction.

Q. But when you refer to four book do you look at the note to see that is corresponds with the number you call out? A. No; I do not—I call out the note next in turn to be used, and in this case it was No. 1562.
COURT. Q. How do you know the number and date you have now stated? A. Our notes are in fifties, and in this case I should call 62—that

would signify 1562—when Mr. Higham delivers the note he does not give me the date—I have a book that shows what notes are to be issued, and I call out the number that comes in order—on this occasions I should say"One 200 is 62"—Mr. Higham would give the note, and I write the name "Rotherham" against it in the book—that does not prove that this is the £200 note delivered.

WILLIAM HIGHAM . I am a clerk in the Bank. On the 5th of January I remember handing a £200 note to a person applying for it—here is my hand-writing on the back of the notes that were given in exchange for it—here are" twelve notes, 115l. in the name of Rotherham, "Under which I put my initials and this ticket for 85l. on which my initials are put—I cannot tell the number and date of the £200 note which I gave to the bearer of these twelve notes and this ticket—I gave out the £200 note of the number which the last witness called out to me—I have the note.

CUTHBERT GEORGE BROWNS . I am a clerk in the Bank. On the 21st of August last, I received this £200 notes are paid in we re
quire the person to put his name and address on them—I did not see the person who produced this £200 note to do—I asked his name, he said "Wrightson"—I find the writing of of my partner, William Taylor, on it.

WILLIAM TAYLOR re-examined. I wrote "5, Bethnal-green" on it, it being imperfect I wrote it again, the name of "Robert Wrightson, Esq., No. 5, Bethnal-green," was on it—I did not see him write it, but I pre
sume he did.

CUTHBERT GEORGE BROWN re-examined. Q. Did the person who pre
sented that note receive any others in exchange for it? A. Yes; one £100 note, one £50, £20, and one£10, they are entered in my writing in the cash-book and in the numerical book—I wrote the name of wright
son against the number of the notes we paid—the £100 is No. 10, 557, dated 6th of August, 1835; the £50 is 16, 584, dated 28th of July, 1835; the £20's are 17, 846 and 47 dated 30th of July, 1835; and the £10 note is No. 9500—the name of Wrightson written against them is the name the person gave in—on the third of October last, I received that £100 note again into the bank.

C. G. BROWN re-examined. This is the note produced by Higham—the mane on it is Joseph Rotherham, 39 and 40, Shoreditch. I delivered ten £10n notes, from Nos. 1955, to 1964, dated 24th of August, 1835—I made the entries, and Mr. Taylor delivered the notes—it would be Mr. Taylor's duty to pay these notes.
WILLIAM TAYLOR . I paid the person who brought this £100 note, the ten £10 notes.
WILLIAM HIGHAM . I produce six £10 notes, Nos. 1955, 1956, 1957, 1960, 1963, 1964, which have again come into the bank.

EDWARD MUSGROVE . I am a clerk to my brother, who is an auctioneer, in Austin friars. I knew Mr. George Andrews—I am not aware of what he is—in the month of September, I received from him a sum of 73l. odd, for some fixtures in a house in Shoreditch—I know the premises for
merly occupied by the prisoner—it was for the fixtures of that house—Mr. Andrews had taken these premises of the party of whom Mr. Mus
grove was acting—Ellis and Howes—to the best of my recollection, I received more than 73l., and gave him change—I think it was in notes—I think I received 75l. I wrote the name of Andrews up on the notes I received.
WILLIAM GIGHAM re-examined. I produce on e£50 note, No. 16, 584,
dated the 28th of July, 1835, one £20, No. 17, 847, dated the 30th of July, 1835, and one £10 note, No. 9500, dated the 21st July, 1835.
MR. MUSGROVE. These are the three notes that I received from Mr. Andrews on that occasion.

GEORGE ANDREWS . I know the prisoner, Mr. William Rotherham—I was acquainted with him four or five years before he came a bankrupt—I knew him carrying on his business in Shoreditch—I was employed to retake those premises for him—it was about four months ago—he asked me to take the house for his brothers Joseph, as he could not get it himself from the landlady—she would not admit Joseph Rotherham as a tenant, and therefore he applied to me to take it for him.
COURT. Q. Did the prisoner want it taken for his brother, and not for himself? A. Yes; and the landlady would not admit his brother.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. In consequence of this, did you apply to Mr. Musgrove? A. Yes; and came to terms—half the amount of the fixtures was to be paid, which was 73l. or 74l. to the best of my knowledge—after this I saw Joseph Rotherham, and his brother, the bankrupt was present when the agreement was made—they gave me the money to pay for the fixtures—Joseph gave it me in the presence of William—I think nothing passed respecting the payment of these fixtures, between me and the pri
soner and his brother when Joseph gave me the money—they were large notes—the same that I gave to Mr. Musgrove, on the same day—the prisoner made no application to me at any time after this on the subject of letting the house—his brother did.
Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. Have you seen Joseph Rotherham write? A. Never to my knowledge—he never kept a retail shop in shoreditch, since I have known him.

COURT. Q. Did you go at any time to these premises, after the fixtures were paid for? A. Only three or four times—Joseph was in possession of the premises, and I frequently saw the prisoner there—the place was not finished.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Was William there when you saw Joseph there? A. Yes; I do not know that he was always there—I communicated with Joseph in the presence of William.

COURT. Q. Had you any communication with William, who employed you to negotiate for the house; as to what sources the money would be re
ceived from? A. No—I understood from Joseph that it was part of a sum of money that he received with his wife on his marriage.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. When did you last see Joseph? A. In October—he was not married then—I cannot tell whether William was present when Joseph explained the sources from whence he meant to pay for these—I think it was at a house opposite the Excise-office, in Broad-street—I had about ten interviews with them together, and separate.

JAMES OAKSHOT . I live in Shoreditch, and am a carpenter. Joseph Rotherham came to our premises on the subject of some repairs—William Rotherham was not there—In consequence of that application I went to the premises in Shoreditch—I saw Joseph—I was at the time the repairs were done, about the latter end of August or September—when I went to the premises, Nos. 39 and 40, Shoreditch, Joseph was in the shop, and Williams was there—there were some drawings shown me by Joseph, in the presence of my partner—we were to be paid 200l. for the work done—I was in the habit of seeing the prisoner while the work was going on

upon the premises—I was not in the habit of conversing with him on the subject of repairs—Joseph was the person we made our contract with, but William could not be on the premises without our passing the time of the day with him—we sometimes spoke to William on the subject—I have re
ceived two sums of 50l. each from Joseph, on account of our bill, in notes.

Q. Have these three £10 notes, Nos. 1960, 1963, and 1964 your writ
ing on them? A. No—I have seen notes similar to these before, at the Bankruptcy Court, but I want to be sure before I answer you—I should say this note has been through my hands, by having "Little" on it, which is my partner's name—this is not his writing—he does not write—I write for him—this is not my writing—there is no writing of mine on these notes—this name of "Doggett" on this one, I believe is my writing—I have not the smallest doubt of it—I believe it is my writing—this is No. 1963.

Q. Do you see anything you think to be your handwriting on the other two? A. This one has my writing on it, No. 1934, and so has this one No. 1960—they have all got my writing on them—everyone of them—I did not tell the Jury so at first—I am not in the habit of writing on notes—I did not observe it at first, when I turned the notes over.

Q. Did you complete the work on these premises? A. I did—the whole of our contract was finished—all what we agreed to do—there was another contract—we were paid nothing on the second contract—there was nothing left undone, to my knowledge—I have no note written by the bankrupt in my possession—I had a note from him relative to this trans
action—I gave it to Mr. Bowden, the solicitor—I have not seen it since—I gave it to him the day after I was examined at the Bankruptcy Court—nearly the whole of our repairs were fixtures—we have got the whole of the counters and shelves back—that was all the fixtures that were the subject of the contract—I gave nothing for them, because we were not paid—we were paid at first—we received 100l—I consider we fixed them up for nothing—we were allowed to take them back by Joseph—I saw the prisoner on the subject of these fixtures when he was in the Fleet, about two months back—I went expecting to find Joseph, but I found the pri
soner—I found we could not get our money of Joseph, and I asked the prisoner what we were to do—he said he found that Joseph could not open the house, and we had better take our fixtures back again, and we said, "Very well, we would sooner do that than lose the whole"—William said that Joseph wanted to be paid a certain sum of money, and he mentioned 50l—I said we could not think of doing any such thing, we were losing enough as it was—he said we should give him 20l—I said we would not do any such thing—he then said I should make him a present of 5l—nothing else was mentioned between the 20l. and 5l.—I forget whether 10l. was mentioned—it might be—I then took away all the fixtures.
COURT. Q. Then it was by William authority you acted, when you removed them? A. Yes.

Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. The contract for these fixtures was entered into between you and Joseph? A. It was during the completion of the first contract William told the men that were working there how to act—how to put up the shelves—he gave directions in the first contract with regards to the size of the shelves, more than once—not to me per
sonally, but in my presence—when I said he never gave me any directions on the first contract, but merely passing the time of day, I meant as to taking the contract—I cannot say whether he interfered more than once—he was there several days when I was not present—he did not give me

directions about the shelves more than once—the direction were given generally, in the superintendence of the work, by Joseph, to me and my partner—I cannot tell on what days I received the first and second 50l.—I believe the name of "Doggett" on these notes to be my writing.

Q. Up on your solemn oath, will you swear that is your handwriting? now take care? A. I will not swear to it—these are the three "Doggetts" that I said before were my handwriting—I will not swear that this one is my handwriting—I will not swear this other is my writing, it very much resembles my handwriting—I have sworn before that I believe it to be my handwriting, and believe the same now.
COURT. Q. What do you say about these two that you have handed up; have you any doubt about this being your writing on them? A. I do not know that I have.
MR. LEE. Q. How do you spell Doggett? A. Doggett; this one is spelt Doggett, this is Daggett, this other is Doggett.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Do you recollect writing upon the notes that were paid to you for the work, the name of "Doggett"? A. I went to Mr. Doggett's to get change for the noes—not for all three, I believe only one—I very seldom write on notes—I recollect writing the name of "Doggett" on one of them—I have no recollection of writing on the other two.
Q. Now once more, look at the whole three of them carefully; do you believe that the handwriting upon each of these notes is yours? A. I should say it was.

COURT. A. Have you any doubt it is your handwriting? A. No; I have no doubt it is—I recollect writing on one at Mr. Doggett's shop—the last time I saw Joseph Rotherham was in the Fleet, about three months ago.

ROBERT WRIGHTSON . I am father-in-law to Mr. William Rotherham, his wife is my daughter; I live in the house where I was born, on Beth nal-green, and where I have lived for ninety years. I can write—I have been in business many years—this "Robert Wrightson, Esq., 5, Bethnal
green "is not my writing—I never had this £200 note in my possession on the 21st of August—I have been our of business a length of time—I never had such of money in my possession—I have had 100l., but I never had this.

Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. Can you tell me those handwriting it is? A. No; I do not recollect any one—I never saw Joseph Rother
ham write.
FREDERICK COLLIER re-examined. I have seen Joseph Rotherham write—I believe this "Robert Wrightson, Esq." to be his writing.

JOHN MUMFORD . I have a brother of the name of Charles—in the be
ginning of 1835 my brother was in some difficulties—I was managing his affairs—this bill (looking at one) was never brought to me, but I saw the prisoner on the subject of it—I went to him about it after the bill became due—I think it was about April or May—I asked him where it was—he said he did not exactly know, he could find it out—he did not at that time produce it to me—there was no negotiation between us about paying it—I wished to know where it was—I called several times about it—I proposed through the accountant, who wished me to go, to give 18l. for it—I offered 18l. for it, on conditions of its being delivered up—I knew the prisoner was a bankrupt at the time, but I did not know where to apply for it—my brother, who intrusted me to make the application, told me it was an

accommodation bill—I do not know that I told the prisoner it was an accommodation bill, but he knew that, I dare say—I made that offer be
cause we understood it was in a third party' hands, and we thought that be paying 2s. or 2s. or 2d. in the pound we might get it—I paid 18l.—I don't know when, but it was after the bill was due—I paid the bankrupt 18l. to take up the bill—I think it was in May or June.

WILLIAM NEWMAN . I am a draper residing at Windsor, and was so pre
viously to 27th December, 1834. I knew the prisoner, William Rotherham—I had seen him once, and done business with him previously to the 27th of December, 1831 he had supplied me with goods—I was not indebted to him toll the 27th of December, when Mr. Newman came to town and pur
chased goods—I was not with her—she came by my direction—I received some goods about the 29th of December, as far as I can remember—I do not know the prisoner handwriting—I know the acceptance of this bill to be my own handwriting—it was given for the goods—I instructed my wife to purchase of Mr. Rotherham.

FREDERICK COLLIER . The filling up of this bill is Mr. Scafe's hand
writing—the signature I believe to be Mr. William Rotherham's.

WILLIAM NEWMAN . I have remitted money to pay this bill to Mr. hay, of Windsor-terrace, City road—the bill became due on 30th March, to the best of my knowledge, and I believe on that day I remitted the money, it being on Sunday—I was well aware it could not be applied for till the 31st—the money was remitted to Mr. Hay where the bill was made payable—I believe the 30th was the Sunday, or else it was 31st—I know it was on Sunday that Mr. Hay ought to have the money to pay it on Monday.

Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. These goods were purchased by your wife? A. Yes—she is not here—she is alive and well—I know nothing more than that these goods followed the order which I supposed my wife gave.

MR. LEE to FREDERICK COLLIER. Q. You say you believe the sig
nature to be the handwriting of the prisoner? A. yes, from having seen him write cheques—the body of the bill is Scafe's—he has been accus
tomed to draw bills for the prisoner—the prisoner was in a very large way of business and was in the habit of signing blank cheques.

EDWARD HAY . I remember, in the month of March, 1835, receiving some money from Mr. Newman, of Windsor—the sum was 35l. and something—a man came at the expiration of the time with a bill of 35l. from Rotherham—I paid the man myself—I never saw the prisoner in my life—if this is the bill the lawyer had, I swear I received it—I kept it my self in my iron chest until Newman himself came, and then I delivered it up.

CHARLES BRISTON . I am the clerk to Mr. Belcher, the official assignee under this fiat of bankruptcy—(looking at a book)this is on of the bank
rupt's book, which was delivered up under that fiat—here is an entry in it in red ink, which was made by the bankrupt at our office after the fiat—it was produced to him at the court, at the time of the examination—this is one of the books produced when he passed his last examination—here is entered on the credit side of Miss. Scafe's account, "May 16th, 1834, Cash 50l.; June 2nd, Cash 50l.; and then, without a date, imme
diately under the last item, "53l. 3s. "
Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. Is is not the regular practice to have the books marked by the Commissioners, as having been exhibited before

them? A. It is generally done at the first meeting—there is a regular stamp used by the Commissioners to mark the books which they have ex
amined, and this book does not appear to be so marked—there were a great many books exhibited under this estate—I generally sort out the books to be produced at the meeting, under the direction of some person—there are a great variety of Commissions, and a great number of books—it happens nearly every day in the week—this book was produced at one of the meetings, and the bankrupt had the opportunity of inspecting it—it was one of his principal books—I do not know whether his atten
tion was called to this particular entry—the book was produced at one of the meetings, and the bankrupt had an opportunity of inspecting it scon
tents—I cannot recollect the amount of debt proved under this commission—nothing has been paid, and I cannot say what they have in hand belong
ing to the bankrupt—I do not keep the books—I do not know that there is at this moment 20s. in the pound—I know the debts to be much larger than the amount of the estate.

MR. WIGHTMAN. Q. Did the bankrupt see this book at the last exa
mination? A. yes, decidedly so—it was with the rest, at the official assignees.

COURT. Q. Is it the custom to exhibit all the books? A. Yes—all the books are generally brought—all the prisoner's books were not pro
duced, because some were very old ones.

JANE SCAFE . I live in Whitby, in Yorkshire. My brother was a clerk at the shop of Mr. William Rotherham—I think I know his handwriting—this account of mine, in this book, is in my brother's writing—he was, for anything I know, the chief clerk, and manager at Mr. Rotherham's; and, I believe, he kept his books—I gave an acceptance for a bill of 123l., about the end of October, 1834—I did not pay 50l. on the 16th of May, 1834; or 50l. on the 2nd of June, 1834; nor did I afterwards pay 53l. 3s—the bill which I accepted was paid by my brother; but I did not see it paid—it was in Yorkshire.

JAMES WILLIAM BUCKLAND . I am a refiner of metals, and a manufac
turer of British plate. I know the bankrupt—I recollect his coming to me sometime after his last examination—somewhere early in the year, but I cannot tell the time—it was soon after he became a bankrupt—I had an interview, (but not at our house,) after he past his last examination—it was at No. 18, Finsbury-square, at Mr. John Scafe's, who had been his clerk—I learnt from the bankrupt that he had passed his examination—he said he was asked at the court whether he had not a valuable gold watch—he said he had a watch in his pocket: and drew it out of his pocket, and put it down, and said, "There is my valuable gold watch;" and there was some observation which I cannot recollect; but he was told, if that was the watch to put it into his pocket—the watch which he produced was a metal one with a bit of string—he showed me the watch he produced before the Commissioners—it was a metal watch—I saw it with my own eyes—he said nothing but Miss. Scafe's debt; but sometimes afterwards I had occasion to go to Holloway to inquire for Mr. William Rotherham—I went, but could not find him—this was, I think, the beginning of August—I returned to Clifton-street, and waited till I saw him—I do not recollect whether he said any thing about re-taking his old premises—the conversation was in consequence of a Bill of Exchange which he had put into circulation—he had a second to take up the first, and he put them

both into circulation—I saw him about this bill on which I was sued—he said he could not do any thing, for that he had saved but 400l. or 500l., and that was every farthing expended; and he had been obliged to pledge his watch that morning to buy a dinner at home for his family—he said he came to Clifton-street to see Mr. Scafe, who had a bill of about £150, which was drawn to Scafe's sister; and likewise there was 30l. in addition to the bill due from Miss. Scafe, and 20l. from Mr. Anderson, making altogether 200l.; and if Mr. Scafe would give him the bill he would make him a present of the remainder of the money, which was about 50l.—he said so—he said about 30l. was due from Miss. Scafe, in addition to the bill; and that Scafe held a bill drawn on his sister.

Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. I believe you are some relation to Scafe? A. yes; we married two sister—no one was present at this conversation—Scafe was not present at that conservation—I am not on bad terms with the bankrupt, nor on good terms—I have been a bankrupt once, which was about September; and I was insolvent once, about twenty years ago—I gave one bill for £195, and I gave a second to make up the first—the first was an accommodation bill, and the second was given to take up the first, which irritated me very much at first—I did not say I would take the first opportunity to make him recollect it—I had the opportunity to do it if I wished—I gave the account I have here when I was subpoenaed by Mr. parker, about a week ago—I mentioned it at my own house, to Mr. Brickley (solicitor) about six months since—I did not send information to Mr. Parker—I told Mr. Brickley, because he was a friend—I do not know where he lives—I had known him twenty years—he is to be found at Fenchurch-street—he was not security for me in any transaction—Mr. Parker lives, I believe, in St. Paul's Church-yard—when I applied for my bills, the prisoner said he had nor a shilling in the world, nor a bit of bread to put into the months of his children—he said he had pledged a watch—that was in the beginning of August.

MR. LEE to MR. BELCHER. Q. Will you tell me the amount of assests? A. His stock sold for about 6, 000l—his goods debts were 1400l——the amount received by me in all, to the 15th of October, was 8, 125l. 14s. 10d.—I do not know the amount of debts proved altogether—the bankrupt made a great mistake, and it was dispute between him and me—it was stated that nearly 2, 000l. had been expended in white-washing, painting, and glazing, and repairing the premises, over and over again, but I had them valved—the officer took the stock at 9, 669l. odd, and it was valued at 3, 000l. more.

MARY WRIGHTSON . I am the sister of Mrs. William Rotherham. I recollect Mr. William Rotherham becoming a bankrupt—I received a parcel from Mrs. William Rotherham after the bankrupt of Mr. William Rotherham—I cannot tell how soon after—I cannot tell where it was—I was living with my father then—Mr. William Rotherham became a bankrupt in Ja
nuary last years—it might be longer than a month after, that I received the parcel—Mrs. Rotherham opened it—the prisoner was not present.

(The prisoner read a long address, entering into the particular of his em
barrasment, and stating, that tit his affairs had been managed judiciously, there would have been an ample surplus after the payment of his debts in
full; and that he had no idea of defrauding his creditors, who had been in advised in their proceedings against him.)
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi: Fifth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
563.
DANIEL FOOT
was indicated for stealing, on the 30th of January, 2 rings, value 31s., the goods of
John Foote, his master.

JOHN FOOTE, JUN . I am a surgeon, and live in Tavistock-street, Co
vent-garden. The prisoner came into my service as errand boy, on Thurs
day, the 28th of January, at 5s. a week—I took two rings from my finger that evening, and placed them in a drawer—I missed them on Sunday morning—the prisoner had absconded at that time—on the Monday morn
ing I took him, and then he asked if I would let him off it he returned them both—he is no relation to me.

WILLIAM BOURN . I am shopman to Mr. Lamp, a pawnbroker, in Stan
hope-street. I produce the ring which I took in from a young man, on Saturday the 31st of January—it was not the prisoner.

JOHN KIRKMAN , I am a policeman. I took the prisoner into custody—he denied all knowledge of the rings—when going to the station-house he said he might as well tell all about it—he took the rings, but did it through distress—I asked what he did with them—he said he had given one to a boy, who he knew very well, to pawn; and the other to a boy who ran away with it.
(Sarah Harding and Richard Wright gave the prisoner a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 15.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Nine Days.

564.
BENJAMIN WALLER
was indicated for stealing, on the 3rd of February, 180 stay-laces, value 3l. 10s., the good of
John Henry Machu his master.
MR. PAYNE conducted the Prosecution.

JOHN NELSON . I have been six months in Mr. Machu's employ. The prisoner was also in his employ, and slept in the warehouse, last Wed
nesday night, about half-past nine o'clock, I came into the warehouse—I had been out for some beer—when I came in, I saw the prisoner in the corner of the warehouse, by the silk laces—he had got the silk laces in his right hand, putting them under a wrapper—there were boxes at his right hand, putting them under a wrapper—there were boxes at his right hand which contained the laces—they were French white laces in the top box, and underneath they were silk-there was a white paper hanging out of the box—I did not say anything to him—we went and sat down by the fire, and drank out beer—about twenty minutes after that, as I was reading, he left me, and went to the staircase, took the wrapper and put it into the gas-meter cupboard—he than came and sat by the fire again—I said nothing to him till the clerk came, at about a quarter past ten o'clock—I had previously made a communication to the clerk and when he came in, I winked at him to send the prisoner away, which he did, and while he was gone—Mr. Machu afterwards came in with a policeman, and said, there was an alarm of thieves in the places, and asked the prisoner if all was right—he said it was, that he had been round the place, and there was
nothing the matter—he changed very white—my asked him how the laces came in the cupboard—he made no answer.
THOMAS HOLLOWAY . I am clerk to Mr. Machu. In consequence of a communication made to me by Nelson, I sent the prisoner out—I have heard Nelson give his evidence—it is corrcet.
COURT. Q. Why did you send the prisoner out? A. Nelson did not know how to act exactly, and he explained that to me.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. How long has he been in your master's service? A. Twelve months—Nelson spoke to me the morning before about this

JOHN HENRY MACHU . I am a silk-manufacturer, and live in Twisters-alley, Bunhill-row, St. Luke's I have heard the statement made by Nelson—it is correct—I said, "Every thing is not right here, there is some thieving going on," or something to that effect—the prisoner, with others, was sitting round the fire at the time—I took a candle, and went towards the gas-meter cupboard—I said, "Come here this moment"—he did not move—I said, "Ben, came here"—he then did not move—I said again, "Come here"—he then came, and I said, "Pull every thing out of this place, "Which he did, but I thought rather reluctantly—I said, "Come, every thing out" and he pulled out with ropes and dirty paper that was there, a wrapper containing the silk laces—I said, "How came they here?"—he made no answer—I said, "You rascal, you put them there"—he still made no answer, but appeared very much confused, and I saw a tear dropping down his face, and when I went in he turned exceedingly pale, and put up his arms—the value of the laces is 3l. 10s.

Cross-examined. Q. Is that the wholesale price. A. Yes—there are fifteen dozen of them—I have no partner in this business—I do not wish to press the charge in any way—he had half-a-guinea a week and a penny a night for his beerhe is not married—he slept in the warehouse for security.
(George Draper, of Bamborough-court, St. Luke's, gave the prisoner good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 18—
Confined One Year.

565.
JAMES STEVENSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 29th of January, 1 looking-glass and frame, value 4l., the goods of
William West.

WILLIAM WEST . I am a broker, and live in West Cottages, Cambridge-health-road. I bought a looking-glass, which I placed where I purchased it—I saw it safe about ten minutes after one o'clock, on the 29th of January—I missed it afterwards—(produced) this is it—I Knew it to be the glass when I was at worship-street; but it is so mutilated and broken all to pieces since—the policeman had an accident with it—I Have every reason to think it is the same—that I saw at Wroship-street was the same.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Who did you buy this furniture of? A. Mr. Wilson, a spirit-merchant—he was confined in the Fleet-prison at the time I bought it—the prisoner was one of the men I employed in removing the things—Mrs. Wilson was in the house when I got there—there was a padlock and chain on the front gate of the house—I did not break that with a crow-bar.

Q. On your oath, did you not tell the prisoner to take the glass to his lodging and keep it till he should see you, as you wanted to dispose of it privately? A. On my oath, no such passed—I conceive Mr. Will.

son had a right to dispose of the furniture, his rent was all paid—I do not think the Sheriff had been in—if he had, he would have prevented my taking the things away and purchasing them—I have never paid for the glass—there was no receipt given, or any instrument drawn up—only a verbal agreement—this was not purchased by auction—the things were not all packed up ready to be take away when I got there—my men took them down, and the glass too—I do not think there was any article, packed up.—I had made the agreement with Wilson some days before, because I had been receiving some furniture perparatory to this—there was no person present at the agreement.

COURT. Q. You employed this man to take the property, did you? A. Yes; as to the removal of the goods—at noon-day—help me to put them into a van—I know nothing more than than seeing the glass on the lawn—I did not see the prisoner take it away—I did not make the bargain at the Fleet, but at the house, prepartory to my seeing him there.

MR. PAYNE. Q. Have you ever been in any other part of this Court? A. Yes; that is not relevant to this question—I have been at Clerkenwell—I indicted a man named Hall, who robbed me of 5l—I was never in
dicted for having sworn falsely.

Q. On your oath, did not ten witnesses swear on that occasion, that they would not believe you on your oath, and the man was acquitted? A. I dare say they could have produced fifty, they were such a set of man—persons came forward to say, and he was acquitted certainly—I was never in Chelmsford gaol, nor any prison in Essex—the prisoner was not em
ployed to take the glass home; but only to get the things into the van.
NOT GUILTY .

566.
CHARLES COOKE was indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of January, 1 copper, value 15s., the goods of
Ann Nash, and fixed to a build
ing against, the statute, &c; and that he had been before convicted of felony.
MARIA NEWTON . I am servant to Miss Ann Nash, of Camden-tow, Kentish Town. She had a copper at her house, fixed to a building—it was lost on the 6th of January—this is it.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. How do you know it? A. By the burn; there was water in it when it when it was stolen—I can swear to it by the burn at the side, and grease inside—I saw it between eleven and twelve o'clock in the wash-house—I did not miss it till the policeman came in the evening—the wash-house is at the bottom of the garden.

ALEXANDER LYON (police-constable S 43.) I was son duty in Camden-town, and saw the prisoner with a copper on the evening of the 6th of January—he went to Mr. Bignell's—I heard him ask Mr. Bignell to buy the copper—I came in, and asked were be got it from—he said, "From Mr. Sherriff of Kentish-town"—I said I was not satisfied, and he must go with me there; and when we got outside the door, he said he had stolen it.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you said he had better tell you all about it? A. No—I left the copper at the shop—I got back again about seven o'clock—I know it was the same I had left, by my initials, which I had put on it—the prisoner said he had stolen it when he came out of the shop—he did not tell me where from.
GEORGE WILLIAM MURRAY . I am a policeman. I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, from the office of the clerk of the Court (read) the prisoner is the man who was tried.
Prisoner. The Policeman has been telling falsehoods.
(William Carroll, a painter and glazier, of Kentish-town Benjamin Swain, a tinman, of Kentish-town; and Edward Gibley, a slater, of Somers'-town; gave the prisoner a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Transported for Seven Years.

567.
HENRY SMITH was indicted
for stealing, on the 18th of January, 1 glazier's diamond, value 16s., the goods of
John Owen Smith; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

JOHN OWEN SMITH . I am a painter, and live in Ironmonger-street, St. Luke's. The prisoner is my son—I missed a glazier's diamond from my house, on the 18th of January—I charged him with taking it—I did not threaten him—I have tried every way I possibly could to make him better—I told him he would have to go back from whence he came—he is my only child—my wife has been dead six years—he told me that I could find the diamond at Mr. Matthews, in Whitecross-street.

WILLIAM HENRY ROYES . I am shopman to Mr. Matthews, a pawn
broker, in Whitecross-street. I produce the diamond—I took it in of a lad about the prison—it is worth seven or eight shillings.
WILLIAM GARROD . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner into custody.
MATTHEW PEAK . I am a policeman. I got this certificate of the Prisoner's conviction from Hick's Hall (read)—the prisoner is the same boy that was tried.

GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Transported for Seven Years.

568.
WILLIAM BLANDFORD was indicted
for stealing, on the 14th of January, 1 book-stand, value 8s.; 6 pieces of velvet, containing 4 1/4 value 5s.; part of a book-stand, value 13d.; 1 pen-rack, value 2s.; 4 looking-glasses and frames, value 8s.; 1 watch-stand, value 4s.; 1 box, value 1s.; 2 dresses and frames, value 1l. 12s. 2 glass bottles, value 1s. 6d.; 3 boxes, value 12s.; and 1 inkstand, value 2s.; the goods of
Charles Thomas Pratt, his master.

CHARLES THOMAS PRATT . I am a cabinet-maker, and live in Vineyard
walk, Coppice-row, Clerkenwell. The prisoner was my journeyman for fourteen months—I missed some things and gave him into custody—he said he lived at No. 10, Bowling-green-lane—I went there and found part of the property and some duplicates, on the 15th, I found this velvet.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Is there any mark on that velvet? A. I have a piece here which this was torn from—this is my box—I cannot swear to this in particular—I had a dozen of them made, and filled them up as dressing-cases—the duplicate of it was found at the Prisoner's lodging—he was constantly in my employ for fourteen months, and had 25s. a week—I believe he has a wife and two children—he has borrowed money of me—I lent him 2l. when he first came into my employ, and he repaid me a few shillings at a time—he did not pay me 2l. 10s. for it—I cannot exactly say how much it was—he asked me some time ago to lean him 2l., for which he accounted to me, I think, 2l. 4s., or 5s.—the loan was for a month or two—I did not charge him 2s. for the loan of 10s. to my recollection I will not swear it—you will understand I never charged him any thing—it was his own offer—he often stopped away from work longer than he should, and I considered he was only paying back my own money.
HENRY ASTELL . I am a pawnbroker. I produce the dressing case, which was Pawned by a man, nine months ago, in the name of John Brown—I cannot swear to the prisoner.
JAMES JONES . I am a pawnbroker. I produce this box—I believe it was pledged by the prisoner, but I cannot swear it—this glass was pledged by a female.

JOSEPH SMALLEY . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner—he told me where he lodge—I went with him, and found these things, and the duplicates of the other property. (Samuel Elliott, a cabinet-maker, of Charterhouse-lane, gave the prisoner a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Confined Two Months.

569.
ELLEN CALLAN was indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of July, two gowns, value 10s. 1 scarf, value 5s.; 1 pair of half-boots, value 3s.; 2 yards of linen cloth, value 2s.; the goods of
Ruth Weighell, now the wife of
John Byfield, and that she had been before convicted of felony.

RUTH BYFIELD . I am the wife of John Byfield, a bootmaker, in vine-street, In July last was a window, and my name was Ruth Weighell—the prisoner was a servant at the London Hotel, in Albermarle-street—at that time I mangle for that house—I missed the property stated—the prisoner came to my house while I was out for a day's work—I found my box broken open, and the property gone—I took them out of pawn my
self.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. There were other people in the house besides me.

ANN PRINCE . I am the wife of Richard prince, and live in Great St. An
drew-street, Seven Dials. I know the Prisoner—in July last the came to me, in Sidney's-alley, and asked me if I knew of a pawnbrokers's—I went with her to a pawnbroker's, and she pawned these articles—when I came out she asked me if I would accept of the tickets—I did not want them—she said she should never take them out, that the gowns wee too small for her, and the boots pinched her—unfortunately I took the ticket—I gave it to Maroney, who went and took the two gowns out for 5s., and left the remainder in, for 5s.—went in a fortnight to get things, and was taken into custody, and taken to Marlborough-street for it.

prisoner. The witness is a perfect stranger to me—about two months ago, I met her in New-street, Covent, but there was no converss
tion between us. Witness. It is no such thing.
SAMUEL HASLOCK . I produce this gown, which was pledged by the wit-Maroney.

BRIDGET MARONEY . I pledged these two frocks at Mrs. Haslock's—Mrs. Prince gave me the ticket, and I took them out for 5s., where they were in for 10s., at Mr. Lawton's in Green-street—they were pledged in the name of Smith.

ANN PRINCE
re-examined. I gave Maroney the ticket when they were in for 10s., because the gowns would fit her, and not myself—the shop
man is not here from Mr. Lawton's, where they were first pledge—it is at the corner of Green-street—I met the prisoner in King-street, Covent-garden.

GEORGE WEIGHELL . I am the prosecutrix's brother. she left me in charge of the house—the prisoner came there that day, and went out with a basket—I went out with some clothes, to take to Jermyn-street, and left

her at home—when I came back I found she was gone, and the key left outside the door—we did not find the robbery out for two or three days—no one else had any opportunity of taking the property, between the time of my coming home and finding it out.
Prisoner. Q. Was not the door left open when you went down into the kitchen—did not go for you, to get you a situation? A. You said you would—I was gone about ten minutes.

THOMAS CLARK . I am a policemen. I got this certificate of the pri
soner's former conviction form Mr. Clark's office, (read)the prisoner is the woman who was tried.
Prisoner. I never took the thinks.

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Transported for Seven Year.

570.
GEORGE HEWSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 18th of January, 1 handkerchief, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
Robert Daniell, from his person.—2nd COUNT, stating it to belong to a man unknown.

ELEANOR STRAFEN . I live in York-square, Commercial-road. I was walking with Mr. Robert Daniell, on Monday night, the 18th of January—I know he had a red handkerchief with him—I cannot swear to it—it was taken from him by somebody.

SARAH HAGUE . I am the wife of David Hague, and live in Church-row On the 18th of January, I was passing along the Commercial-road, and saw the prisoner and another boy walking behind the gentleman and lady—I saw the other boy hold up the pocket while the prisoner put his hand in, and drew the handkerchief out, all but the corner—the gentleman walked on—the wind blew it of, and it dropped—the prisoner picked it up—he said to the other, "Jack, take it, and run away with it"—the other ran, and I saw no more of him—I hid hold of the prisoner, and tapped the gentleman on the shoulder, and told him his pocket was picked—he turned round, and took hold of the prisoner—this is the handkerchief.

Prisoner. This young woman was coming along—the handkerchief blew on the ground—I picked it up—she said it is the man's handkerchief—I said I knew it was—I was going to take it to him—I gave it to her—she ran up, and I after her—when I came up to the gentleman he said, "Who picked my pocket?—"I found it, Sir, but I have not picked your pocked." Witness. Yes, he said, "I have picked up your handkerchief"—I told him I had seen him draw it out, all but the end.

GUILTY . Aged 13.—
Transported for Seven Years.

571.
THOMAS STEVENS was indicted
for stealing, on the 12th of January, 1 pattern, value 20s., the goods of
Edward Narbrough and others, his masters—2nd COUNT, calling it a model.

EDWARD NARBROUGH . I am a brass-founder. The prisoner was in my employ—about nine o'clock, on the 12th of January, as he was going away, in consequence of information, I said I wanted him—he said, "What for?—I said I thought he had something about him that did not belong to him—he turned round, and made towards the street-door—I had fastened that. and he could not get out—he said, "I want a drop of water"—he went to the water-bull, and I after him, and he dropped this pattern.
JOHN GREEN . I am a policeman. I was called in, and took the prisoner and the pattern.
Prisoner. Mrs. Bennet asked me to go into the shop, and get a towel,
and I asked her if I should bring a pattern out—she said I might if I liked, and I said I would.

EDWARD NARBROUGH
re-examined. some of this property belongs to Mr. Bennett—he and his wife, I believe, promised to give him some half
pence if he would bring the pattern out.

THOMAS BENNETT . I have known the prisoner two years—I have been in the prosecutor's employ three years, and upwards, and during that time the prisoner was in my employ, and paid by me—these trifling things I had hanging over my mantel-piece, as an ornament—I took some of them with the prosecutor's knowledge to cast for a friend—was had a few words, and I left there, and locked up the pattern before I left—the prosecutor saw me do it—I said, "I had no particular occasion at this time for them, I suppose I can take them at any time"—he said I could—my wife met the boy, and he said he was going to leave his employ-then she said, "Tom, you can go to work for your old master again"—she said, "You can bring your clock, which will suit to lay on"—he said, "Yes, and he had a pattern which he could bring at the same time—she said, "Yes, you can"—I did not know it—it was done unknown to me—I was two miles from the shop—it was innocently done between him and my wife—she would have been here, but was confined this morning—this pattern is my pro
perty.

EDWARD NARBROUGH
re-examined. It is his—it was left in my pos
session—he owes us money—the prisoner said Mrs. Bennett offered him some money to get it.
NOT GUILTY .

572.
JOHN JUDAH, alias Jones
, was indicted
for stealing, on the 28th of January, 1 cheese, value 14s., the goods of
James Pearson.

THOMAS JOHNSON , I am shopman to Mr. James Pearson, of East-street, Marylebone. About two or three o'clock, on the 28th of Janu
ary, a neighbour opposite came and told me something, in consequence of which I missed a cheese—I had seen it safe hall an hour before—the prisoner was pointed out to me by somebody—I went and brought him back—when the prisoner was in the shop, he said, "I do not want to have any bother about it, I know where the cheese is; I will return it, and make you a handsome present"—I said I could not it, and gave him into custody.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did you tell this to the Magistrate? A. I did—Mr. Thackray was present when this occurred, and two wit
nesses—I could have brought a dozen—he was pointed out to me directly after I missed the cheese—he did not say he would rather give me a cheese than have any bother about it—he said he knew where it was—the cheese was taken within a hundred yards or so, just round the corner, where he was lost sight of, and it was cut up into four pieces—I was in
formed of that.

PHILIP THACKRAY . I am a carpenter, and live opposite the prosecutor's shop. I was at the window of my first-floor, on the 21st of January, and saw the prisoner take the cheese—I am sure he is the man—I went and gave information to Mr. Pearson—I saw the prisoner again within five minutes—I caught him and took him into the shop—he positively denied it at first, and when I came to be positive with him, he wanted to com
promise with Johnson, and said he wanted to make it up.
Cross-examined. Q. Tell us what it was he said? A. That he did not

know any thing about the cheese—he afterwards said he knew where the cheese was, and he would make Johnson a handsome present, if he would do nothing further in it—I did not hear all about it—he took it down the street, towards Castle-street—I told the shopman within three or five minutes after it was taken, and saw the prisoner again in about two minutes—he was then returning round the corner—he passed Mr. Pear
son's shop again, and went into the pawnbroker's close by—he came out again in a minute or two, and I gave charge of him—it was done momen
tarily—I cannot he mistaken—it is a middling-sized street—I only saw his face for about half a minute—I followed him, but he had got rid of his load before I got to him—I lost sight of him at the corner of Dorset-street for about one moment; and almost directly afterwards saw him coming in an opposite direction.

COURT. Q. You saw him take the cheese? A. I did, and ran after him—he had then the cheese with him—when he was returning he was walking very indifferntly, without the cheese—I am sure he said that he would give Johnson a handsome present.

SIMON NEWLAND . I am a coach-trimmer, and live at Holloway. On the 28th of last month I was in East-street, assisting an acquaintance of mine who lived there to move some goods—I saw the prisoner with the cheese in his hand, passing by—I was standing outside the door, about six doors from the prosecutor's nearer to Dorset-street than the shop—the person passed me with the cheese on his right arm—I did see what became of him—a crowd of twenty or thirty people were round the door afterwards, and I went to see what was the matter—the prisoner was in the shop—I went in and said I saw him go up the street with a cheese on his arm—the prisoner said to Johnson that he would make him a hand
some recompense and bring back the cheese, if he would say nothing about it—the lady belonging to the shop said, "No; it was only last night we had part of a ham stolen, and we will not put up with it any longer"—I am in employment as a coach-trimmer at the present time, and have so been for years—I have worked in one situation for fourteen years.
Prisoner. The last witness tells you a falschood about the cheese—I know nothing about it—I was tipsy that day, the policeman who took me can prove it.

THOMAS TURSEY . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner into custody—he seemed to he quiet sensible—he might have been drinking, but he was not drunk—he gave the name of John Jones at the station-house, and Judah at the office—I heard no conversation—Johnson gave him in charge
Prisoner's Defence. I know nothing about the charge—the policeman. knows I was tipsy.

(Moses Judah, a cloth-warehouseman, of Houndsditch, the prisoner's uncle; Andrew Hesham, perfumer, Commercial-road; John Judah, clothesman, Nottingham-place, Commercial-road, the prisoner's uncle; and Alexander Max. tailor, Commercial-road, gave him a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 38.—
Confined One Year.

573.
JOHN SMITH was indicted
stealing, on the 3rd of June, 4 hall-crowns, and 30s., the monies of
Joseph Morris, his master.

ANN MORRIS . I am the wife of Joseph Morris, a butcher, in Cable-street, St. George's-in-the-East. The prisoner was in our serviceon the 3rd of last June, I gave four half-crowns and thirty shillings, and sent

him to purchase meat for the shop—he did not come back—I never saw him or the money after, till I saw him on the 27th of January at Worship-street, on another charge—I went into his bed-room and found all his clothes gone, and the money also.

Prisoner. My mistress gave me the money, but my master would not allow me to go to the market—I gave the money to him—Mr. Morris has seen me several times since. Witness. It is not so—my husband had another shop at the time—he said nothing of this sort before the Magis
trate, or I would have brought my husband.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Nine Months.

574.
NORAH MAHONEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th No
ember, 1 bedstead, value 2s., the goods of
Richard Burn.

RICHARD BURN . I am a fruiterer, and live in Little Shire-Lane. In October last the prisoner lodge in my house, and continued there till the 7th of December—I missed a bedstead, and charged her with having taken it—she said she did not expect I should take her up for so trifling a charge—I told her, after living rent-free for so many weeks, and committing such a number of depredations, I must—I went to Cornelius Mahoney, in Wild-court, Drury-lane, and there I saw the bedstead.
Prisoner. I had it six weeks before I went to his house—it is my own and not his. Witness. It is mine I am sure.

ALICE LILEY . I Live at Mr. Burn's I saw the bedstead in the collar in October, before the prisoner came to the house—I have seen it since—it is his, and was so before she came—it had a sacking on then.

BRIDGET MAHONEY . I am the wife of Cornelius Mahoney, and live in Wild-court, Drury-lane. The prisoner gave me the bedstead that was found at my house nine weeks before Christmas, and said her brother gave it to her before she went to live there—she lived on the third floor, in Wild-court—she had it in the room—I am no relation to the prisoner—I always knew her by the name of Macarthy—she lodged in the room a bedstead in the room, and she did not want that, so she let me have it—there was no sacking to it then.

JAMES NOCKALL , I am a policeman. I charged the prisoner with this—she said she did not think Mr. Burn would prosecute her for so sim
ple a thing.
Prisoner. I did not say any such thing; it is false; tell the truth. Witness. I swear that is the truth.
Prisoner's Defence. I owed him 3s. rent, and he said he should give me in charge because I ran away with his rent.

RICHARD BURN
re-examined. She does own rent, but I freely for
gave her when she left the house—I have no object in this prosecution but justice, nor had I the least idea of punishing her—I should not have thought of finding this bedstead, only on 26th of January my bed-room door was broken open, and my drawers ransacked of every thing; I had reason to suspect the prisoner, and I had proofs of two instances, but I told her I would forgive her for that.
