CHARLES JONES . I am shopman to Mr. Folkard, a pawnbroker, in Commercial-road-east. I produce two hymn-books pawned at my master's shop. on Thursday, the 14th of January, by the prisoner, in the name of William Morris—I asked him if they were his own property, and he said, "yes"—I am quite sure of him.
JOHN BARTON . I attend St. Paul's Chapel. I was there on Sunday, the 3rd of January, at the afternoon-service—this book is mine, and was left in my pew that afternoon—I do not know the other book.

RICHARD COLEMAN. I am shopman to Mr. Latter, a pawnbroker in Commercial-road-east. These two hymn-book were pawned on the 14th of January, by the prisoner, in the name of John Barton—I am quite certain of him.
GEORGE WEBBER, This is my book—I attended at the morning service, and left it locked up in a case.
JOSEPH SELWIN . I am a pawnbroker, and live in Waterloo-terrace,
Commercial-road. I produce a psalm-book, pawned on the 14th of January, by the prisoner, in the name of "John Morris"—I am sure he is the man.
FOLIAT SCOTT STOKES . I am one of the congregation of St. Paul's Chapel—I do not think I was there on Sunday, the 3rd of January—this hymn-book is mine—I left it safe there on Christmas-day.

WILLIAM CRUSH . I am a pawnbroker, and live in Museum-street. the prisoner came to my shop on Saturday, the 23rd of January, and offered me a prayer-book and hymn-book in pledge—these are them—I had received information of this robbery the day previous—I took the books from him sad asked him what he wanted—he said, 7s.—I asked him if they were his own—he said, "Yes"—I said. "Where did you get them from?"—he said, "I bought them"—I said, Did you? "—he said, "Yes; I have had them these seven years—I beckoned my lad over the counter, seeing the name of Statchard in the book, and sent him for a policeman—I then told the prisoner I was much mistaken if they were not taken from a chapel at Clapham—he said he could soon convince me of the contrary, as they were his own property, and his friends were respectable—I gave him in charge.
prisoner. I deny part of his statement; he asked me a question of what I wanted, nor whether they were my own, Witness. I say I did ask him those questions previous to beckoning my lad.

GEORGE SMITH . I attend St. Paul's Chapel constantly—this prayer book is mine—I used it, and left, it there on the 3rd of January, in the afternoon—my name was in it, which is taken out, but I know it by marks in it—I had it recently bound, and have had if fourteen years.

PETER LOCKYER . On the 23rd of January, I was called to Mr. Crush's shop, and the prisoner given into my custody—I told him this was stolen property, and asked him if it was his own—he said it was his own, and he had brought them to pledge—he was searched, and seventeen duplicates found on him at the station-house—we went through Thornaugh-street on our way, on the right hand side—Culliford delivered me seventeen more duplicates.

MARY CULLIFORD . I live in Thornaugh-street. I found seventeen duplicates in the area of my house, which I gave to the officer—a person pass ing along the street could drop them down my area—my house is on the right hand going from the pawnbroker's to the station-house.

GEORGE COLLIER . I am a policeman. I was sent for to the station-house, on the 23rd of January, when the prisoner was there—a Prayer book and hymn-book were produced—I asked the prisoner how he came by them—he said he bought them when he was well off, that he had been well off in his time, and in the habit of having a good quantity of books—I asked how long he had had them—he said for years—I said he had kept them very clean, and asked him if he had got any more books—he said he had been obliged to pawn his books and cloths, being very much reduced, and that he had been living at the Antelope, at Wandsworth—that is about a mile and a half from the chapel

Prisoner's Defence. I was down at the Greenwich rail-road, looking for work—a man came and asked if I could read—I said I could—he said, "I have just picked up a parcel of tickets, I don't know what they are"—he showed them to me—I said, "It is tickets of books"—he said if I gave him a shilling I might have them as they were no use to him—I said, "They are no use to me"—he said, "You may have some of them, if you will stand

a pot of beer—we went and had a pot of beer—he gave me about twenty of the tickets, and I took some of the things out to put them in again, thinking to get more money—I got sixpence more for the first two, and some I could get no more on than they were in for—about ten days afterwards, I was in a coffee-shop in Borough-market, and the same man came in—he asked what I had done with the tickets—I said I had lost them—he said he was distressed, and asked me to buy the ticket of a jacket—I said I had no money—he asked me to stand a pint of coffee for him—he said, "I dare say you made enough out of the other tickets"—after having the coffee he said, "I have got more, you may have them"—and he gave them to me—I went two days afterwards, and took out the red books, at Grosvenor-street, and pawned them for sixpence more—and when I went to pawn them. I was taken into custody—I knew nothing of their being stolen, or I should not have taken them out of pawn to get 6d. and run the risk of being detected—it is false my pawning any on the 7th—I was never in the shop till I went to take them out—another says I had a fustian jacket on—I have never had such a things for years.

GUILTY .—
Transported for Life.
Before Mr. Justice Vaughan.

607.
JOHN REYMAN was indicted
for burglarioulsy breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
James Reyman, about the hour of ten in the night of the 10th of January, at St. Mary, Lambeth, with intent to steal, and stealing therein 2 ounces weight of tea, value 7d.; 1lob.; weight of butter, value 6d.; 1lb. wight of sugar, value 6d.; 2lbs. weight of mutton, value 9d.; 1 loaf of bread, value 3d.; 1 1/2lbs. weight of candles, value 3d.; the goods of the said
James Reyman; and 1 shirt, value 1s.; 1 pair of gloves, value 6d.; and 1 basket, value 1s.; the goods of
Jeremiah Reyman.

REBECCA REYMAN . I am the wife of James Reyman, and live in Bond-place, Bond-street, Commercial-road, in the parish of Lambeth. I am the prisoner's mother—he is a slater's labourer. On Sunday night, the 10th of January, I fastened the house up, at about half-past eight o'clock—I locked the door—there is no back door—the window was fastened with a catch, and a nail put into the frame to keep—it together—I went to bed about half-past eight o'clock—there was nobody in the house, but my husband and myself—we both went to bed at the same time—say husband came down first in the morning, but he is not here—he is very ill—he went down about half-past six o'clock, and called me down—I came down directly after him, and found the street door partly open—the lock was not forced—on examining I found the window had been broken—the middle pane of the upper frame had been put in, and three pieces in the bottom pane were broken out to admit an arm to unfasten the window—it was perfectly safe when I went to bed—the window was shut down again, and the door open—before I went to bed I had put my son Jeremiah's shirt, which I had washed for him, on the back of a chair, towards the fire to air it—he does not sleep in the house—it was gone, and the provisions which I had laid in for the week were gone—there were two ounces, of tea, one pound of sugar, very nearly one pound of butter the best part of a half-quartern loaf, and about one pound and a half or two pounds of pork—they were taken from the cupboard, which was not locked I am sure they were they when I went to bed—I do not know where the prisoner lodged—he was sometimes at home, and sometimes not—a

pair of gloves belonging to his brothers, and a basket were also gone—I saw the prisoner at the station-house on Monday, the 11th of January, and identified the shirt he had on to be the shirt I had bung at the fire that night—I can swear to it—I had cut the collar down, and sewn a piece on it—I know it by my own work—it is my son Jeremiah's—the prisoner was in the habit of coming to my house, back wards and forwards, and we gave him shelter when he wanted it—he was not in service at this time—he was always at liberty to come to the house when he wished.

JEREMIAH REVMAN . I am the prisoner's brother. I left the shirt with my mother to wash, on the 3rd of January,—I live in Devonshire-place, kennington—in Consequence of what I heard from my mother on the 11th of January, I went in search of my brother, and about three o'clock in the afternoon I saw the policeman take him in Webber-street—I went to the station-house about five minutes after with my mother, and knew the shirt on his back to be mine—I am quite sure it was my shirt—I never lest it to him.
Prisoner. Q. Did not you give me into custody? A. No; I saw the policeman take you—he had information of the robbery.

JOHN COLLISON . I am a policeman. On the 11th of January, I received infromation at the station-house, that the prosecutor's house was broken into—we suspected the prisoner, and went in search of him—about three o'clock in the afternoon I saw him coming into Webber-street, and took him to the station-house—I found the shirt on him, which I produce, bot nothing else.

WILLIAM BRIDES . I met the prisoner in Bond-street, on Sunday night, the 10th of January, at a quarter before twelve o'clock, going towards John-street—he had a wicker-basket in his hand—I knew before.
MRS. REYMAN re-examined, I am sure of this shirt, by my work—I left the key inside the door.

p.rs: GUILTY of stealing only. Aged 23.—Recommended to mercy,

div1.p: Confined Two Months.
Third Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

608.
JOHN GAY was indicted
for stealing, on the 31st of January, 4lbs. of pepper, value 8s.; and 2lbs. of mustard. value 2s.; the goods of
John Hunt, his master.

GEORGE WILSON (police constable L 62) On the morning of the 31st of January. I went to No, 2, Salamanca-court, Lamneth, and found the prisoner—I told him I had received information from a female that he had been robbing his employer—he went up stairs—I followed him, and saw him unlock a box, and take this parcel out—he came down stairs, put it on the table, and said it was Cayonne—I asked him where he got it from—he said it was Mr. Hun's—he said, "There is the stolen property"—I took him to Mr. Hunt's and he again said it was his property—it contained 4lbs. of Cayenne pepper—I returned to his house, and found 2lbs. of mustard in the same box.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. He made no difficulty about it? A. None whatever,

JOHN HUNT . I live in Prince's-street, Lambeth, The prisoner was two years in my employ—he was brought to my house with this property—he asked me if his wife had been there—I said she had, and she had made a charge against him of robbing me, but I said I did not belive it, and or
dered her cut of the yard—he said it was true, and what the policeman.
has got was my property—I had very great confidence in him—he had the whole management of this department—I grind the Cayenne myself.

Cross-examined. Q. How long was he in your employ? A. Two or three years—I thought him a good character—the mustard was not produced—he treated this very jocularly—I have been robbed of many times by servants without prosecuting them. that I was obliged to prosecute him—I think he did not expect that I should—he had 28s., a-week.
(Thomas Bullock, of Rochester; and William Thomas Burley, engraver, James-street, New-cut; gave the prisoner a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 40.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Three Months.

609.
GEORGE HATT was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of February, 23lbs. of soap, value 7s.; and 3lbs. of tallow, value 1s.; the goods of
John Hunt, his master.

JOHN HUNT . I am a soap-manufacturer, and live in Prince's-street, Lambeth, The prisoner was two years in my service—in consequence of information from the last prisoner's wife, who brought me in some soap, which I knew could not be got without the prisoner's knowledge—I sent for a policeman, and called the prisoner to me—I said to him, "Can you account how Gay came in Possession of this soap?"—he said he did not know—I said, "He could not have it without your knowledge"—he said "I know nothing of it"—I ordered the policeman to search the prisoner's house, and he found the articles stated in the indictment—I was liable to a penalty of 500l. for concealing it—it is not in bars—it has been cast into different garden-pots, and different things, instead of bars, and taken away—the prisoner's house is on my own premise, in my yard, but entirely under his controul—when he was taken to the station-house, he said he was surprised his stock was so large, and if he had known it he would not have taken so much—the soap weight 23lbs.—it is worth about 4 1/2. a pound, in the state it is in—we make it in a frame, the size of which is according to the act of parliament, but not a bit of this could have paid the duty,

GEORGE WILSON . I was called to Mr. Hunt's and went to the pri
soner's house—I found a basket on the ground-floor, with some tallow is it—he said he did not know the tallow was there—I went up-stairs and found a quantity of soap in a box which has been produced—he said he did not know his wife had so much in the house—when I came down stairs for the basket which the tallow had been in, I found a great quantity of soap, had been put into it, which had not been there before.

JOHN HUNT
re-examined. I have a great quantity of tallow on my premises, of the same sort as this—I do not allow them soap for their con sumption, except on the premises, to wash their, hands—he had 16s., 6d. a-week, with coals and house-room—he could earn 3s. or 4s. a-week more if he liked, as he was a handy man at box-making.

Prisoner's Defence. I hope you will be as mereiful as possible—I took the soap for my wife to wash with, but for no other purposes; not to make profit with—I did not know she had more in the house than was sufficient to use.

GUILTY . Aged 42.—
Transported for Seven Years.
Fourth Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

610.
JOHN THEAK was indicted
for wilful and corrupt perjury.
MR. BODKIN. conducted the prosecutor.
EDWARD HENRY BURRIDGE . I am attached to Union Hall. I produce
a summons against Mr. Cullingford, for keeping his house open during divine service—(the summons was here put in and read.)
Cross-examined by MR. DUNBAR. Q. Were you present at the hearing of this? A. Yes; part of the time—the summons was dismissed—there is wirtten on the summons "dismissed, with costs."

MR. EDWIN. I am one of the clerks of Union Hall. I have got the minutes of evidence which I took in the case of Thomas Stowell aganist Robert Cullingford—(read) "John Theak, of No. 8. Union-place, Newington says; on Sunday, the 6th of December, a at twenty minutes before one o'clock in the morning, I was by the defendant's house—I saw two respectabel men go into the house, and at the same time two men come out with pipes in their mouths; and soon after a female came out with a mug of beer—I had a watch which I compared with Newington Church, and found it correct. "

Cross-examined. Q. What, do you call twenty minutes past one o'clock in the morning; you call past twelve o'clock afternoon? A. I should call it so—the name of the defendant's house is not stated in the deposi
tion—I do not remember hearing the oath administered—the prisoner was ordered to pay the costs of the summons, which were 2s. or 3s., I belive—the same defendant was brought up before, but I cannot tell how long before(I belive within six months) by the same informer and the same witness—I belive the fine was 40s.
MR. BODKIN. Q. What were the names of the Magistrates present? A. James Trail and Henry Jeremy.

THOMAS DAVID TAYLOR . I am a solicitor, and am concerned for Mr. Cullingford—I attended on the 13th of December, when this cast was heard at Union Hall, before Mr. Trail and Mr. Jeremy—the prisoner appeared as a witness—he was sworn to tell truth, the whole truth, and nothing bot the truth—he was then examined, and his depositions taken and road by the clerk—the Magistrate dismissed the summon with costs—I asked Mr. Jeremy what costs I was to receive—he said 3s.—I cross-examined the prisoner, and while the Magistrate was speaking to me, Mr. Cullingford had paid 3s. instead of my receiving it—I thought it was no matter.

Cross-examined. Q. Your client pleaded not guilty?" A. Yes—the name of the house is written up. "Country Terrace Tavern, "but the right name is County Coffee-house—they should alter it—it is situated in the county Terrace, New Kent-road.

JOHN HOWELL . I am a tailor, and live at No. 108, London-road. I know Mr. Cullingford, who keeps the Country Coffee-house—I work for him—on the Thursday before Sunday the 6th of December, I received an order from him for a waistcoat—it was no done in time to be there before church began or the Sunday, and I went to get there at the time church was over, but I got there about ten minutes before one—I met Thomas Miles on the way, and he walked with me—when we got here the door was shut—Mrs. cullingford was in the bar-parlour—there is a window from there, which looks into the street—I looked through, and saw her there—I held the handkerchief that contained the waistcoat up to the window—she knew me, and the door was opened by the boy who goes by the name of Henry—on going, in, Mrs. Cullingford was just coming out of the bar-parlour into the bar, apparently to go up-stairs I should Presume—the bar-maid was in the bar at the time—nobody quitted the house when I went in.
Q. Could two men have left the house when you and Mr. Miles went

in, with pipes, without your observing them? A. Certainly not—nobody went in at the same time with Mr. Miles and myself—I found no female with a mug in her hand, as if served with beer—no female went out—I staid at the bar a minute and a half or two minutes, and after that went into the parlor—I had a view of the tap-room—there were no people there—the door makes a very great noise when it opens—it is in a dilapidated state, and tied at top and bottom—there is a stone flooring, and the bolt shoots makes a noise—I might not have heard that door open, if the parlour door had been shut, but I had the parlourd-oor in my hand, waiting for Mr. Cullingford to come down stairs, and in the situation in which I was placed I think the front door could not have opened without my seeing it—Mr. Cullingford came down stairs shortly, and we had some talk about the waistcoat—while we were talking, the pot-boy came to the room door, and told him it was near the time to open the house—I think he said it wanted about two minutes and a half to the time—Mr. Cullingford said. "Go up and look what o'clock it is, "and he went—Mr. Cullingford said, "We will not open the door, we had better be a minutes or two after than before the time"—there is a window on the staircase, which looks out on Trinity church clock—it would not he necessary to open the front door to see that—I and my friend stopped in the parlour a few seconds, and then came out of the parlour—the door was opened—it was then minutes past one o'clock.

Cross-examined. Q. Dues this house stand at the corner of a street? A. Yes—what is called St. George's-road—there is no side-door—there are a pair of gates in the court, (which no one that I saw was admitted in or out at,) at which Mr. Cullingford was in the habit of taking his beer and lumbering things in—the parlour is in front of the tap-room—I should think it was from ten to twelve feet from the parlour-door to the street-door—I spoke to Mrs. Cullingford first—I looked into the tap-room—there was no clock in the tap-room—there is one in the bar, which I presume was going, as when I came out it was something like ten minutes past one o'clock,—I did not look at the church-cook then—the landlord did not say his clock was out of order—he sent the boy to look at the church-clock, because he wished to be accrete, through being falsely sworn against before—the people who swore against him saying, that there were six people with pipes in their mouths came out of Mr. Cullingford's—from that he was very cautious—he and I are on terms on intimacy, and he has told me he would be cautious, and make the boy look at that clock to see the time before he opened his door—I have heard him say he meant to have prosecuted the people who swore against him—the house is known either by the "County-terrace Tavern," or the "County-terrace Coffee-house"—I waited there five minutes before Mr. Cullingford came down—there is no room between the tap-room and parlour—the stain come down, and there are two doors—there is but one footway—door out of the house, and no back way only those pair of gates—till Mr. Cullingford came down I am sure no person could have come in or gone out without my hearing it; and I should think not, while I was talking to him, because the boy came in and made this remark to him—I stood close to the parlour-door—I swear people could not come in or go out with our my hearing or seeing them; and no one went out—I am sure they could not, for I recollect that Mr. Cullingford and I were talking. and I told my friend that he had been fined a few

weeks before, and he was obliged to be a little cautions—he had got his waistcoat on then—I did not say, I could not certainly say, whether any body came in and went out; I said I thought not; and now, from some circumstances, I am sure they could not—the parlour door was not shut at all—we did not sit down—I had something to drink—I do not think I took any thing till church was over; but I will not swear any thing at all about it—he did not pay me for the waistcoat—I think it was not one o'clock—I will not swear whether it was before or after—I might call for it, and leave it there—I took nothing at any other house that morning.

THOMAS MILES . I met Mr. Howell on Sunday morning, the 6th of December, and went in with him—he made motions to some one at the bar window, and then a lad opened the door—no persons came out at the time we went in—I am sure no two men with pipes came out—the door was closed when we went in—I did not see any female inside, with a mug, getting beer—I suppose we remained in the house from twenty minutes to half an hour, I cannot say—I do not remember any thing being said about the time—I did not see any people come in before one o'clock nor the front door opened.

Cross-examined. Q. That was very good liquor you had? A. I had no liquor at all—we had some ale after he came down, and he had the waistcoat on—I left about five or ten minutes after we had the als—I do not think Cullingford drank—Howell and I did in the parlour—we had no command of the passages or doors at all—people might have) come in or gone out—there was no conversation in my presence about catching the people as the clock struck one.

Q. When did you first hear you were to be a witness? A. About a fortnight or three weeks ago—Howell knew where I lived—he never told me I was wanted till after they were before the Magistrate—I was first applied to about eight or ten days ago—some person brought me a sub
pœns, but I was not at home.

MR. BODKIN. Q. Were you or Mr. Howell nearest the door? A. I sat up by the fire-place, and Howell stood nearest the fire-place—that is not near the door—the door was open, and the fire-place is opposite it—the street door was closed while I was there.

ROBERT CULLINGFORD . I am a licenced victuller, and keep the County Coffee-house, in the Kent-road. It is larger than a beer-shop—I remem
ber Sunday, the 6th of December, Mr. Howell came to bring me a waistcoat at ten or twelve minutes, before one o'clock—my wife brought it up to me—I put it on, and came down stairs, and found Howell and Miles—the front door was shut then—on my oath it was not open from the time I came down, till one o'clock, for no purpose whatever—my boy, Jacobs came to me and stated it was one o'clock—I told him he had better go up and look at the Trinity church, whether our clock was right or no—he came and told me it wanted about two minutes, and a half—I altered my own lock, and then opened the door, and let him out with his beer.

Cross-examined. Mr. Howell was there when you altered the chock? A. Yes; he was in the parlour—the clock is in the bar—I said nothing to him about altering the clock—he heard the conversation—Howell had a glass of ale to drink—I think it was a pint of ale they had—when I came down stairs, I did not look at the clock to see what time it was—I did not know where Miles lived till after this transaction—I called on him to give evidence, I think the day before I was summoned at Union Hall—Mr. Howell and I went—the boy went first, I belive, to see if Miles was
at home, and then Mr. Howell went to him, and saw him, I believe; but I did not—he lives about a quarter of a mile from my house—I did not attempt to bring him forward till about nine days ago.

EUNICE CULLINGFORD . I was at home on Sunday, the 6th of December. Mr. Howell came with a gentleman, about ten minutes to one o'clock—I was in the parlour, adjoining the bar—it has a bow-window, which looks into the street—the door was closed when Howell came—there were no people there for beer, nor any with pipes—I directed the door to be opened for Mr. Howell, because he held the waistcoat up to the window, that he was going to bring home for Mr. Cullingford—the door was closed again directly they came in—nobody left our house with pipes in their hands or mouths—I remained there three or four minutes after they came in, and then took the waistcoat up to my husband—I did not come down again till considerably past one—there was no female there for beer, or any leaving the house with a mug of beer in her hand.

Cross-examined. Q. How many servants are there in your house? A. Four; none of them have the liberty of serving or taking money, ex
cept the bar-maid—I believe she was drawing the boy's beer when I went up with the waiscoat—it wanted about five minutes to one o'clock then—there was no one in the bar besides, but the pot-boy—a person in the par
lour cannot see the bar, unless they stand against the door—I did not come down till twenty minutes before two o'clock.
MR. BODKIN. Q. Was that a large quantity of beer that was sent out? A. About twenty pots, I believe.

MARY ANN MARQUET . I am bar-maid at the house in question I was there on the 6th of December—Mr. Howell and Mr. Miles came in shortly before one o'clock—nobody left the house with pipes when they came in, nor any women with beer—no woman came in at all.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you draw the ale for Mr. Howell? A. Yes. one pint—I was not in the same room they drank it in—they stopped till after the house was opened—my master alters the clock regularly every Sunday morning—I do not know who altered the clock that morning—whether it was Mr. Banks or the man—he is a clock-maker—the clock always gets on a little in the week—sometimes it varies a minute—it is generally altered about half-past ten o'clock in the morning, and some body had altered it that morning.

COURT. Q. And there is a church clock? A. Yes; Trinity church—our clock is regulated ever Sunday morning by that—I cannot tell whe
ther Mr. Banks did it, or master.

HENRY JACOB . I was in Mr. Cullingford's service on the 6th of De
cember—I opened the door to Mr. Howell and Mr. Miles by my mistress's order—she was in the bar—the door makes a noise—there are four bolts to it—you cannot open it without making a noise—no two men went out with pipes, or without—no person came in or went out between Mr. Howell's coming and the door being opened—I asked my master, who was in the parlour with Mr. Howell and Mr. Milles, if I was to open the door—he said not till one—we never open till one—we have got two clocks, one in the bar, and one on the staircase—that is an eight-day clock—I looked at the church clock first, and the other afterwards—my master had good reasons for being particular, because he informed against us once before—I looked at the clock, and then told my master—nobody did any thing to the clock in the bar—it did not want any thing doing to it, because it is always right, and it is regulated every week—every Monday morning—I

know the prisoner—I never said I would serve him out—I would have done him, if I had caught him—we never risked ourselves in his hand to be informed against any more—he false swore against us the first time.

THOMAS DAVID TAYLOR
re-examined. The prisoner saw Mr. Howell before the Magistrate, and heard me examine him—he said he was one of those persons who went in—I sent Howell for Miles, but he would not attend that day—I offered, if the Magistrate would adjourn the case, to produce him next day—the Magistrates said they were quite satisfied, and dismissed the case.

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Confined One Month, and then
Transported for Seven Years.

p.hi: Fifth Jury before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
611.
JAMES WALLIS and
JOSEPH FIELD were indicted for
steal
ing, on the 30th of October, 10 lbs. of onion-seed, value 16s., the goods of
John Biggs, their master.

JOHN PAYNE (police-constable V 11.) In consequence of information, on the 1st of January, I went to Mr. Draper's a gardener, in the parish of Richmond, and he produced 10lbs. of onion-seed, which I now have in my possession—I took the prisoner Wallis into custody on the 2nd of January—I said I wanted him—he said, "You want me for that onion-seed"—I had not said any thing to him about onion-seed.
Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Where does Mr. Draper live? A. Between Kew and Richmond.

JOSEPH BEACH . I am foreman to Mr. John Biggs. In the middle of October I had some onion-seed of Mr. Biggs—it was in the drying-house—I missed some at the time, but I cannot precisely say what quantity—the drying-house cannot be shut up—on the 2nd of November last I had some onion-seed in the barn—I lost some at that time—I was cleaning it—I fastened the barn door by the hog yard—I attached the chain on the staple, fastened it with the pin, and hit it in with a stick—I seedbeds it with a rope, and took the key away in my pocket—when I came back at one o'clock, and unlocked the front barn door, which is in the yard, I found some persons during my absence had broken the door open by the hog yard—I missed a quantity of onion-seed—It was precisely the same as this—it resembled it exactly.

Cross-examined. Q. This took plate in November? A. I missed some once in October from the drying-house, and once in November, of the same quality—I can notsay that other hardeners have not the same seed.

THOMAS STREET . I am a market-gardener, living at Richmond. I bought some onion-seed for Mr. Draper, or rather I agreed with Kendall for it at 1s. 6d. a lb—it was in a handkerchief—I know nothing of the bag—it was a similar sort of seed to this, that I bought and sold to Mr. Dra
per—that was three months ago.

WILLIAM KENDALL . I am in the employ of His Majesty as a gardener. In October last, the prisoner Wallis asked me whether I could get him a customer for some onion-seed—I said I did know, but I knew some persons where I worked, and I would ask them—I saw Mr. Street the next day and asked him—I saw Wallis the next day—he asked if I had heard of any one—I said Mr. Street wanted to see a sample—I took a sample over—I cannot say whether this is the seed—it was similar—I told Wallis on Saturday night, that if he would take it over to Mr. Street he would have it, and give him 1s. 6d. a lb. for it—he said very well, but he could

not take it over on Sunday morning, as he had got nobody to took after his teams—he asked if I could do such a thing—I did it without fee or reward—I think it was some time in October—I told Wallis I had sold the seed, and gave him the money—no one was there at the time, but I saw Field go into Wallis' afterwards—no the same Sunday, when I went down to get saved I saw Field, and he asked me if I had sold the onion-seed—I told him I had, and paid Wallis the money, 15s.; and he said, "Wallis gave you 1s., did not he?"—"No," says I; then Field offered me 6d., and said, "Waills has not given me enough by sixpence; he only gave 7s. "—after that Wal
lis asked me if I could get him a customer for some more—I said I could not—the seed was something similar to this.

Cross-examined. Q. Is there not an enormous quantity of seed of that description about at market-gardeners? A. O yes—I know nothing of that sack—it was in some sort of a cloth—I think it was not later than October, but I cannot say.
J. BEACH re-examined. I know these men—they are carters belonging to Mr. Biggs—they both worked for him at the time I lost the onion-seed—they had an opportunity of knowing where the seed was.
Cross-examined. Q. I suppose Mr. Biggs employs a great many other men? A. Yes; and the drying-house was open.

THOMAS BICKNELL . I am a police-inspector. I gave directions for the apprehension of Field—I asked him whether he knew a man of the name of Wallis (who had previously been in custody); he said, "Yes; but is was not for the last seed that was stolen from my master. "

Cross-examined. Q. Do you think it necessary to give any caution be
fore you put question to a man you have in custody? A. I neither threat
ened him nor promised him any thing—I had another person in custody, and, in consequence of his statement, I asked the prisoner that.

JOHN BANKS (police-constable V 124.) I apprehended Field—I heard him say he received 7s. of Wallis, not for this seed, but some other—I said nothing—he said he could keep his own counsel and say nothing about it in a breath.
NOT GUILTY .

612.
THOMAS HOGAN was indicted
for breaking and entering a build
ing within the curtilage of the dwelling-house of
Frederick Farrand, on the 7th of January, at St. Mary Magdalene, Bermondsey, and stealing therein 1 saddle, value 5l.; one bridle, value 2l. 10s.; 1 crupper, value 6s.; and 30 account-books, value 20s.; the goods of the said
Frederick Farrand; and 6 saws, value 2l., the goods of
Henry Turner Munyard; and 2 saws, value 9s.; and 1 jacket, value 3s.; the goods of
Thomas lsaac.

HENRY TURNER MUNYARD . I work in the employ of Mr. Frederick Farrand, of Long-lane, in the parish of St. Mary Magdalen, Bermondsey. I am a carpenter—I was at work there on the 7th of January, and at six o'clock I left work—I left my tools in the shop, at the back part of the premises—there is a fence and yard—the shop is within the yard, adjoining the house—on the Thursday evening, when I left work, I saw all the men out of the shop, and locked the shop door—I left six saws, hanging up at the end of my bench—I went at seven o'clock the next morning, and found a ladder stationed at the counting-house window—I saw the window had been broken—the counting-house forms part of the same buildings—there was room enough for a man who was not of every large dimensions to get through the place—I found the counting-house had been torn about, the cupboard broken, the shop door broken open, and the marks where a chi
sel

had been applied to the bolt of the lock—I went into the shop, and missed six of my own saws, and seven belonging to parties who were at work with me—I received information that a man had been stopped with some saws at the station-house—I went, and saw thirteen saws—six of them are mine, these are them—I had seen the saddle safe in the count
ing-house half-an-hour before I left.

THOMAS ISAAC . I am a carpenter, and work on these premises. I had some saws safe that evening—there were two mine stolen—they were found on the prisoner—he had a flannel jacket of mine on, when he was at Union Hall.

FREDERICK FARRAND . I examined this counting-house, which had been all safe on the evening of the 7th—my attention was called the next morning to a ladder raised to the counting-house, and the window had been broken—I found the door of the workshop had been opened—I went and found the cupboard broken, all the locks were forced, except the iron safe—the drawers and closets had been ransacked, the books and bills were all gone; and the saddle, which had been left there the night before—the bills and papers were all found in this bag, which was stowed away under the shed, ready to be carried away—I should suppose the saddle was worth about 3l.—this is crupper of it—there can be no doubt this is my crupper.

HENRY SNOOK (police-constable R 80.) I was on duty on Grange-road, Bermondsey, on the morning of the 8th, and saw the prisoner with thirteen was on his back—I stopped him, and asked him where he was going with them—he said, to a new building at Dartford, for the man to work with them—I asked where he brought them from; he said, Long-lane—I asked him who was his employer; he mentioned some name which I do not remember—I said I was not satisfied, and he must go to the station-house—I took him there—he had a flannel jacket on, which I produce—the saws were tied up with the crupper, which is here.

Prisoner. I was very much intoxicated. Witness. No, I do not con
sider you was—you had been drinking.

Prisoner's Defence. I was coming down Long-lane; on the road-side I saw something white, which was this jacket; and under it were the saws—I thought of taking them home till I found the right owner, and I should get rewarded.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Transported for Seven Years.

620.
ISABELLA MARIA PLACEY was indicted
for staling, on the 23rd of January, 3 pairs of Gloves, value 5s. 6d.; 9 pieces of bobbin, value 4d.; 6 pieces of tape. value 1s.; 11 reels of cotton, value 1s. 4d.; 8 pairs of stockings, value 7s. 10d.; 16 yards of printed cotton, value 7s.; 1 1/2 yard of holland, value 1s. 6d.; 5 yards of Irish linen, value 9s.; 3 pairs of stays, value 8s.; 6 yards of flannel, value 8s.; 15 handkerchiefs, value 7s.; 550 needles, value 2s.; 1 shawl, value 6s. 9d.; and 1 yarn handkerchief, value 1s. 6d.; the goods of
Jesse Hallett and another, her master.

JESSE HALLETT . I am a draper and haberdasher, and live at Rother
hithe, and have one partner. The prisoner was in my employ between nine and ten months. On the 23rd of January, I searched her boxes, where I found three pairs of gloves, nine pieces of bobbin, and a variety of other things, which are mine—they had not been sold.

GEORGE SMITH . I am shopman to the prosecutor. Part of this pro
perty was found in the prisoner's boxes, and part under her bed.

Prisoner. The gloves and the handkerchief were bought.
GUILTY. Aged 33.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Six Months.

614.
MARY MILES, alias Hogan, alias Margaret Mills
, was indicted
for stealing, on the 10th of January, 1 watch, value 2l.; 1 watch-chain, value 6d.; 1 seal, value 3d.; 1 watch-key, value 1d.; and I tobacco-box, value 6d.; the goods of
Joseph Woollard, from his person, and that she had been before convicted of felony.

JOSEPH WOOLLARD . I live at Lewisham. I came up to London to see my brother—I happened to meet the prisoner about two o'clock in the morning on the 10th of January—I believe it was in the Dover-road—I believe I spoke first, and she took me up a back lane—she took my watch and my tobacco-box away—I had only been with her a few minutes—I had not given her any thing, or made any bargain with her—she took my watch and tobacco-box in a minute, and ran away—I went after her with the policeman—she had got about thirty yards, or more—I had not given her these things.

Prisoner. You asked me to have something to drink, and took me down that place, because there was a light at the corner, and asked if you could be with me all night, and I said no, because I had a husband—you said, "Never mind, come and stop with me"—You said you had no money, and gave me the watch to keep till Monday morning—the case fell off, and I picked it up, and put the watch in my bosom, and then you—I got from you by telling you there was a policeman coming. Witness.; No, I did not.

CHARLES BURRAGE , (police-constable M 77.) At a quarter-post two o'clock in the morning on the 10th, I heard the prosecutor say he had been robbed of his watch and his tobacco-box, by a woman who was with a man in a smock-frock—I saw the prisoner run across the road, and join a man—I stopped her, and asked the prosecutor if she was the woman—he said she was—I put my hand to her bosom, and felt the watch and the tobacco-box—the prosecutor had been drinking, but knew what ho was about—he said if the box was his the rivet was out, and he had put a large pin in, and turned it up, which is the case.
Prisoner. Q. You found the case off the watch? A. Yes, and the glass was broken—the prosecutor said it was whole he had it.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
JOHN WOODHOUSE (police-constable M 13.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got at Mr. Clark's office—I know she is the same person (read.)
Prisoner. I never was tried only for a drop of drink.

GUILTY . Aged 37.—
Transported for Fourteen Years.

p.hi: Sixth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
615.
LOUISA WAYCOTT and
WILLIAM WAYCOTT were indicted for
a misdemeanour.
NOT GUILTY .

616.
LOUISA WAYCOTT was again indicted
for a misdemeanour.
NOT GUILTY .

617.
ANN SMITH, alias Betsy Waters
, was indicted
for a misde
meanour.
MR. CHAMBER conducted the Prosecution.

ELIZABETH SIMS . I live in Bridge-street, Lambeth, and am a tobac
conist. On the 28th of December, the prisoner came to my shop, between seven and eight o'clock in the evening—she asked for half an ounce of snuff—it came to 2d.—she gave me a shilling—I gave her the change—my daughter came into the shop, and said it was bad—I called in an officer, and gave her into custody—I gave the constable the same shilling.

Cross-examined by MR. DUNBAR. Q. What light had you? A. We have two gas lights, one in the window and one on the counter—the shilling was not out of my hand—we both looked at it, and called the constable, who was passing—I had given the prisoner the change, and then snatched it from her—she did not say, "If you object to the shilling, I do not re
quire you to take it"—she said at the station-house that she had it from a gentleman.

MR. CHAMBERS. Q. Did you receive a shilling from the prisoner, and hand that identical shilling to the policeman? A. Yes; it never went out of my sight till I gave it to the officer—I went to the station and marked it.

DAVID FORSTER (police-constable L 33.) I was called into the prose
cutor's shop. I took the prisoner to the station-house—I searched her there and found a good half-crown in her hand, but no other money—she objected to be closely searched by me—a woman was sent for, but found nothing on her—she said she took the shilling from a gentleman—Mrs. Sims delivered me the shilling—this is it—I asked the prisoner her name—she said, "Ann Smith"—she objected to tell where she lived, but after
wards the said she lived in High-street, Marylebone.

Cross-examined. Q. Did she object to be searched by a woman? A. No—she kicked me violently—that was not when I wanted to search her—I went to take hold of her arms and rub down her breast—I did not see her throw any thing away—I have never said that she did—she was remanded for a week, and then discharged.

JOHN BUSHILL . I live at No. 7, Portsmouth-place, Kennington-lane, and am an apothecary. The prisoner came to my shop on Friday night, the 8th of January, between five and six o'clock, for a pennyworth of pill
cochia and an ounce of salts—she placed on the counter a shilling—I gave her 10d. change—on taking up the shilling I found it was counterfeit—I took the money away from her, and the shilling, and gave her into custody—she told me she took it of a gentleman—I asked where she lived—she said in Jews'-row, Chelsea—I marked the shilling, and gave it to the officer.
THOMAS WHITEHEAD (police-constable L 103.) Mr. Bushill sent for me. I took the prisoner, and he gave me this shilling—the prisoner said her name was Betsy Waters.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you search her? A. No; a woman searched her—there was nothing found upon her.
JOHN FIELD . I am Inspector of counterfeit coin to the Mint. These shillings are both counterfeits.
MR. DUNBAR. addressed the Jury.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Twelve Months.

618.
JOHN WHITE was indicted
for a misdemeanour.

ELIZABETH GREENAWAY . My master is a baker, and lives in Ber
mondsey-street;

his name is King. The prisoner came there on Saturday evening, the 30th of January—he bought a 1d. loaf, and gave me a shilling—I put it in the till—he after came again—no other person had been in the shop—he asked for another 1d. loaf—I served him—he offered me another shilling—I discovered that immediately to be a bad one—I told him so he said he would give me another—I refused to take it, and called Mr. King, my master—he fetched in a constable—I took the shilling he first gave me out of the till and showed it to Mr. King—Mr. King gave then both to the constable.

Prisoner. I only went in once that evening—I gave you a shilling—you refused it, and I gave you another. Witness. I told him he was the man—he said, "It was not me, it was a man with a dark coat," he is the man—I have no doubt of the prisoner.
WILLIAM GREENAWAY KING . My servant called me out of the parlour—I saw the two shillings—I gave the prisoner into custody to the policeman.
JAMES WHOWALL (police-constable M 166.) I was called in to take the prisoner—I recevied these two bad shillings—I searched the prisoner, and found one good shilling on him.
JOHN FIELD These are both counterfeit, and from the same mould

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Twelve Months.

619.
JAMES LLOYD and
JOHN DINSDALE were indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of January, 10 wooden staves, value 15 s; and; pieces of wood, value 5s.; the goods of
the Company of Proprietors of the Grand Surrey Canal, the masters of the said James Lloyd.

THOMAS GEORGE MORRIS . I am in the employ of the Surrey Canal Company, as a constable. On the 19th of January, I was on the premises between eleven and twelve o'clock—I saw Dinsdale just inside the gate, coming out with a horse and cart—the cart appeared loaded with lath wood, but on examination, I found it contained staves and deal ends, which had been taken from the bonding-yard—I had asked him what he had got beside lath wood, and be answered, "Nothing"—when I found these other things, I asked him how he came by them—he said a man gave them to him; that he did not know his name, but he should know the man if he saw him—I took him down to the bonding-yard, where there were four men at work—I pointed to one man and said, "Is that the man?"—he said, "No"—I then pointed to Lloyd, and said, "Is that the man?"—he said, "Yes"—Lloyd is a deal porter—he works for the company occasionally—I asked Lloyd if he had given Dinsdale any staves or deal ends—he said, "No;" he did not know any thing at all about giving it—Dinsdale said, "You did give it me, Jem, you know you did, and I promised you some beer"—I asked Llyod to go with me to the Superintendent of the Dock, and he went directly.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. What time did you begin to unload the cart? A. A little after eleven o'clock—the men go to dinner at twelve o'clock—Charles Henry Davis, John Brown, and William Roach, were at work with Lloyd—I think it was between eleven and twelve o'clock when I took Dinsdale to the bonding-yard, and pointed out Lloyd to him—I think it was before the men went to dinner, but it might be after they returned—I had unloaded the cart first, and it took some tine—the men must have passed by where the cart was, to go to dinner—I will not swear it was not past one o'clock.
JAMES MARNEY . I am a labourer in the Surrey Dock. I was at work

in the corn-granary adjoining the bonding-yard, which is where the staves are kept. I saw Dinsdale there loading his cart—he had some lath-wood and part of a deal end in the cart—I looked again, and saw him putting a stave into his cart—he had a boy with him—I then went across the loft to the back door, and saw Lloyd take up two deal ends, and two staves, and place them down; and in five minutes I saw Dinsdale take them up and hand them to the boy in his cart.

SAMUEL TOWERS . I am foreman of the bonding-ground I received information while I was in the Dock-office, of a cart having been stopped at the gates—I went and saw ten staves which had been taken out of the cart—I had seen them before in the bonding-ground—they were the property of the proprietors of the Grand Surrey Canal—hero is their Act of Parliament.
MR. PAYNE called.

WILLIAM ROACH . I was one of the men employed in the bonding-yard, at the Grand Surrey Canal, with Lloyd and the others—I remember seeing Morris unloading the cart at the dock entrance at a little after twelve o'clock, as I was going to dinner with Lloyd, Brown, and Davies—we all went to dinner, and came back at the usual hour—it was after that that Morris brought some man to the bonding-ground, and Lloyd was taken away.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. The first you saw of Morris was when he was unloading the cart? A. Yes—I suppose it must have been loaded first—it was after we came back from dinner that Lloyd was taken—he worked in all parts of the premises—some of these staves were kept in the bonding-ground, and some not.
JURY to SAMUEL TOWER. Q. Was it the duty of Lloyd, in his employment, to remove the staves? A. He had nothing to do with them—the deal ends he might have to remove.
(Eight witnesses gave Lloyd a good character, and seven witnessed gave Dinsdale a good character)

JAMES LLOYD—
GUILTY [Recommended to mercy by the Jury. See original trial image.] Aged 38

JOHN DINSDALE—
GUILTY Aged 45. Recommended to mercy by the Jury.

620.
REBECCA CLARE was indicted
for feloniously receiving on the 22nd of December, of a certain evil-disposed person, 2 pairs of boots, value 18s., the goods of
John Matthews, knowing them to have been stolen, against the Statute, &c.

JOHN MATTHEWS , I am a shoemaker, and live in the Blackfriars-road I only know the prisoner by seeing her at the public office—I lost a great many boots and shoes, but I do not know when they were taken.

HENRY MOORE . I am shopman to Mr. Powell, a pawnbroker, in Suffolk-street. I produce a pair of boots, pawned on the 31st of December, to the best of my recollection, by the prisoner, in the name of Ann Clare, No. 19, Surrey-row—I cannot say whether she was alone.
Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. Did she give her right address? A. Yes; and her right name.

JAMES EDWARDS . I am in prisoner for taking these shoes—I live in Red-cross-street, Borough, with my father and mother—I worked at Mr. Matthews's—I remember about the 22nd of December taking some boots of my master's—I believe it was five pair—I gave them to Sarah Pope—I never gave any to the prisoner—Thomas Pope used to come and receive them from us—William Freeman lived at Mr. Matthews's, and he assisted.

me in robbing my master—he went there just after Lord Mayor's-day—he was an errand-boy, and I was the same—I do not know the prisoner—I only went with her to pawn two pairs at Mr. Powell's in Sufflok-street, and Mr. Powell's in Park-street—Sarah Pope knew the prisoner, and she went with her to pawn them, and Pope gave us threepence a-piece.

WILLIAM JOHN FREEMAN (a prisoner). I am twelve years old. I was errand-boy to Mr. Matthews—Edwards and I used to rod my master of shoes and boots—we used to take them in the evening, about seven or eight o'clock—we stole about fifty pairs—Thomas Pope used to come to the shop, and we gave them to him—he used to take them home—I do not know the prisoner—I never gave her any thing—only she and Sarah Pope pawned two pairs, and I and Edwards waited outside—Pope gave us threepence a-piece.
COURT to JOHN MATTHEWS. Q. Did either of these boys state in the presence of the prisoner that she had pawned these boots? A. Yes; at the presence-office.

HENRY BARRETT . I am a police-constable. I apprehended the prisoner for receiving the property—I searched her place, and found a duplicate of another pair of boots pledged in her name, at Mr. Davis's in Union-street—Freeman said at the office that she had pawned two pair of boots.

MR. DUNBAR. Q. Do you remember when you took the prisoner? A. Yes; on the 4th of January—I found her in bed, but did not take her then—I returned in two hours, and found her in bed with her husband—we took them both to the station, as I understood they had both received considerable property—the prisoner said she was innocent—I was at Union Hall when the boys were examined—these boots were not produced the first time—they were at the second or third—the pawnbroker was examined there—I was there at the second examination—the clerk took down what the prisoner said.
JAMES ATFIELD . I am a police-constable. I was present at the prisoner's second examination. Mr. Taylor, the clerk in attendance, I believe, took the depositions down.
NOT GUILTY .
Sixth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

621.
JANE DOORS was indicted
for feloniously receiving on the 28th of November, 2 pair of shoes, value 8s., the goods of
John Matthews, have been stolen against the Statute, &c.

JOHN MATTHEWS . I live in Blackfriars-road. William Freeman and James Edwards were in my employ——they are admitted as evidence in this case—the prisoner was servant to Mrs. Roberts, a lodger of mine—I think she left seven or eight weeks ago—I lost a large quantity of boots and shoes—these two pair of shoes are mine—I had the information of the boys for having given them away—I have missed such articles—these have been worn, but I know they are my make—I had not sold these—I have the prisoner's own evidence for taking them, and the boy's evidence for giving them—I think I have lost between three and four hundred pairs altogether—whether it all happened while the prisoner was a servant in my house, I cannot tell.
JAMES ATFIELD . I am a police-constable. I went to the prisoner's and found one pair of these shoes; my brother officer found the other.
WILLIAM HENRY BARRETT . I am a police-constable. I went on the 4th of

January to No, 7, Gilbert-street, Clare-market, where the prisoner lived, as the lodgers informed me—she was not at home, I waited, and apprehended her at the door—I asked her if she knew any thing about any shoes of Mr. Mathews—she said she had received two pairs from the boys Edwards and Freeman, and that she had then one pair on her feet—I than took her to the station-house—these are the shoes.

JAMES EDWARDS (a prisoner) I am twelve years old—if I don't speak the truth I shall go to hell—I lived with Mr. Matthews—I used to steal his shoes—I began to do so before Lord Mayor's day—Jane Doors came and asked Freeman whether he could get a pair of shoes for her to wear—he said he did not like to give them without I would, and I said I did not like to do any such thing—in two or three days Doors came and said if we would give her a pair to wear, and a pair to pledge, she would give us 6 s—I said I did not like, but we stole two pair the next day, and Freeman put them into the dust-hole, down stairs, and Doors took them—she told us to put them there—she was going away then, and she did not come back any more—we did not get the 6s. for them, not any thing at all—they were the only two pairs she had—I did not see her afterwards—I had only been one week with her—I swear that is the truth, and the whole truth—Freeman and I took about fifty pair, but Doors had only two pairs—I cannot say whether she took any others herself—these are the two pairs we gave her, I am sure—I could take my oath they are—we did not take any other of this sort—these were the first we took—the prisoner went home at night.

Prisoner. He said if I would pledge two pairs, and give him the money, he would give me one pair for myself—I pledged one pair at Mr. Allen's and one pair at Mr. Walmsley's and the third pair I had, which I wore myself, Witness. I never asked her to pledge any.

WILLIAM JAMES FREEMAN (a prisoner). I am twelve years old—I do not know what will become of me if I do not tell the truth—I do not know what will become of the wicked—I have heard of such a place as heaven, and such a place as hell—I do not know who go to heaven—I do not know what will become of me if I do speak the truth—I have never been to church—I was two months at Mr. Matthew's—on Sundays I used to brush the shoes, and clean the windows, till one o'clock, and then I went home to my mother—she is a milk-woman, and live in Union-street—I have one sister, and two brothers.

Q. Do you mean to say you never went to church in your life? A. Not as I know of—my mother has told me it is wrong to tell lies—she never told me that people who tell lies go to hell—I do not know how I came to be admitted as king's evidence.

Q. You were examined before the Grand Jury, and I am told you told the foreman that you knew what an oath was, and what would become of you if you told a lie? A. Yes I do know what will become of me if I do not speak the truth—I know if I do not tell the truth I shall go to hell, Sir.
JURY. We cannot belive this boy.

JAMES ATFIELD I was present at the prisoner's apprehension—I heard her say the boys Freeman and Edwards gave her two pairs of shoes—one pair she had on and one pair was pawned at Mr. Allen's—I went tole the pawnbroker need not attend, as he could not identify the person.
JOHN MATTHEWS . I cannot tell when I missed these shoes—it was

within two months of the close of December—these were not the first I missed—I missed others before these, six or seven rows from some stacks—I and my wife were ill, and could scarcely get out of bed—I did not propose that these boys should give King's evidence—I believe Mr. Dunbar received instructions to that effect from the boy's mother.
NOT GUILTY .

622.
JANE DOORS was again indicted
for feloniously receiving, on the 30th of November, 1 pair of shoes, value 5s., the goods of
John Matthews, well knowing them to have been stolen.
WILLIAM ROBERTS I live at Messrs. Walmsley's pawnbrokers, in Drury-lane, I have a pair of new shoes pawned by the prisoner on the 28th of November in the name of Hutchings.
JOHN MATTHEWS . This prisoner came to my house about two months before Christmas—these are my shoes; I have lost such—I have not sold any of this make—they have my private mark on them.

JAMES ATFIELD I am a police-constable. When the prisoner was apprehended on the other charge, she told me she had taken a pair of shoes from Mr. Matthews, and pledged them at Mr. Walmsley's in Drury-lane.
Prisoner. No; I said I received them.
WILLIAM HENRY BARRETT . I am a police constable. The prisoner said she took this pair of shoes from the shop, and pledged them in Drury-lane.

Prisoner. I had only had those which the boys gave me—they gave me these—they told me they might take a hundred pair from the shop, and nobody know it, as the master was in the habit of going out at seven o'clock every evening, and not coming home till two o'clock in the morning, and then quite or nearly drunk.
MR. MATTHEWS. The prisoner had access to these shoes—she used to pass through the shop many times a-day—my shop is very full of goods—any body passing might take a pair here and there.
NOT GUILTY .

623.
SARAH POPE and
JANE SCOTT were again indicted for
feloniously receiving on the 22nd of December, 1 pair of boots, value 4s., the goods of
John Matthews, well knowing them to have been stolen.

JOHN ROSS . I am a pawnbroker, and live in the Blackfriars-road I have a pair of boots, pawned on the evening of the 22nd of December, by the prisoners—they boy came into the shop—I knew them both—I cannot tell which I took them of—they treated them as their own property—they pawned them for 2s.—they are worth 3s., 6d., or 4s—the name of "Ann Claire, 19, Surrey-road, "is on the duplicate
NOT GUILTY .

624.
SARAH POPE and
JANE SCOTT were again indicted for
feloniously receiving on the 1st of December, 2 pairs of boots, value 5s., the goods of
John Matthews, well knowing them to have been stolen.

WILLIAM HENRY BARRETT . I am a police-constable, I apprehended the two prisoners at the Victoria Theatre—I understood they had two pairs of boots given them by Freeman—I took them to the station-house and got the boots from their feet.
NOT GUILTY .

625.
SARAH POPE was indicted
for receiving on the 2nd of January, 1 pair of boots, value 6s., the goods of
John Matthews, the same having been feloniously stolen, well knowing them to have been stolen, against the Statute, &c.
JOHN HOOKER . I am in the service of a pawnbroker, in Union-street. I produce a pair of women's boots, pledged by the prisoner, on the 4th of January.

Prisoner. When I was at Union Hall, he said he could not swear whether I pledged them or not. Witness. My Lord, I swore it positively, as will appear by the depositions—these are what are termed Adelaide boots.
JOHN MATTHEWS . I know these boots are mine, I lost such—they were stolen out of my shop window about the 2nd or 3rd of January.
JAMES EDWARDS William Freeman stole these boots and gave them to Thomas Pope.
NOT GUILTY .

626.
THOMAS POPE was indicted
for receiving, on the 2nd of January, 1 pair of boots, value 4s., and 1 pair of shoes, value 4s., the goods of
John Matthews, the same having been feloniously stolen, he well knowing them to have been feloniously stolen, against the Statute, &c.
HENRY MOORE . I live with Mr. Powell, a pawnbroker. I produce a pair of boy's boots, pledged at my employer's shop, by Joseph Clare, I believe.
WILLIAM HENRY BARRETT . I am a police-constable. I produce another pair of shoes, which I got at Mr. Powell's.
JAMES EDWARDS . This is a pair which I gave to Thomas Pope to give to Sarah Pope.
NOT GUILTY .

667.
JOSEPH CLARE was indicted
for receiving, on the 24th of December, 1 pair of boots, value 8s., the goods of
John Matthews, the same having been feloniously stolen, he well knowing them to have been stolen, against the Statute, &c.

JAMES ATFIELD . I am a police-constable. I produce a pair of hod-nail boots, which I found at the prisoner's house, No. 19, Surrey-road—the prisoner was in bed, and the shoes were by the bed-side—I told him I wanted him for receiving a pair of boots of Mr. Matthews, knowing them to he stolen—he said he had bought them if Freeman, and given 3s., 6d. for them—Freeman was present at the time, and he contradicted him, and said he had not given him any money, but he was to give it him on boxing-day—I took the prisoner to the station.
Prisoner. You cannot expect that these boys will tell the truth, when their master came into the prisoner and gave them halfpence not to tell the truth.

JOHN MATTHEWS . I know these boots are mine—the prisoner acknowledged he received them from the boy; and the boy said he gave them to him, and he was to give him 3s., 6d., for them; but he had not—I had hut this pair of this sort—I think lost them in the month of December—I have not sold this pair, if the boys were to be believed.
JAMES FREEMAN . On Christmas-eve Mr. Clare came to the shop, and said if I would get him a pair of boots out, he would give me 3s., for them—I
took them out one at a time, and gave them to him—he told the other boy he was to give 8s., for them.
Prisoner. I never saw this boy on Christmas-eve.
JOHN MATTHEWS These are worth 9s. to me—I have seen the prisoner round my door.
NOT GUILTY .

div0.p: The King against MARCUS WARSCHAUER, alias Warsower, alisas Mordecai Moses .

The learned Judges having confirmed the conviction of the above pri
soners, which took place at the last December Session, the following judments have been passed.

ROBERT BALLS and
THOMAS HARRIS — Transported for Life.
MARCUS WARSCHAUER — Transported for Fourteen Years.
